topic:
Hubble Telescope Achievements

Identify positive accomplishments of the Hubble telescope since it was launched in 1991.  

Documents are relevant that show the Hubble telescope has produced new data, better quality data than previously available, data that has increased human knowledge of the universe, or data that has led to disproving previously existing theories or hypotheses.  Documents limited to the shortcomings of the telescope would be irrelevant. Details of repairs or modifications to the telescope without reference to positive achievements would not be relevant.


You are a classifier for "Hubble Telescope Achievements" since its 1991 launch.

RELEVANT if any of these hold:

- Mentions new or higher-quality data produced by Hubble that wasn't available before.
- Shows how that data expanded our understanding of the universe or overturned past theories.

NON-RELEVANT if any of these hold:

- Focuses **ENTIRELY** on repairs, technical issues or upgrades without linking to any positive achievement.
- Describes limitations or general mission plans without concrete Hubble discoveries.

&UR; ATTENTION EDITORS: &LR;  The following is the budget for the New
Scientist for material available the week of MON., JUNE 5, 2000,
and anytime thereafter. This material is free for use for New York
Times News Service clients. &QL;


   ROCKETS OR RAINFOREST


   ROCKETS-DESTROY-RAINFOREST-NEW-SCIENTIST-NYTSF &LR;  &QL;


   Guyana's agreement to sell a large patch of swampy rainforest to
a Texan rocket-launch company, has angered environmentalists.
Critics say the launch site will destroy ancient archaeological
remains, drain the pristine swamp, level forests and throw families
out of their homes.


   DESTRUCTION OF CHEMICAL WEAPONS IS DEADLY SLOW


   CHEMICAL-WEAPON-CLEANUP-STALLED-NEW-SCIENTIST-NYTSF &LR;  &QL;


   Officials from Russia and the United States have told The Hague
that they will not be able to keep their promises to destroy their
chemical weapons by April 2007. Russia simply hasn't got enough
cash while the United States has a lack of clean disposal
technology.


   SECOND SIGHT


   REVAMPED-HUBBLE-TELESCOPE-NEW-SCIENTIST-NYTSF &LR;  &QL;


   A revamped Hubble Space Telescope could peer back in space and
time. Astronomers and telescope builders in the United States have
come up with a plan to give the aging Hubble Telescope a new lease
on life by sending up huge new mirrors, instead of rebuilding an
entirely new space telescope.


   STOP THE BLEEDING WITH SOUND WAVES


   ULTRASOUND-HALTS-HEMORRHAGING-NEW-SCIENTIST-NYTSF &LR;  &QL;


   Doctors may eventually use sound waves to halt hemorrhages deep
within the body without having to slice into a patient. A team in
Seattle have discovered that high-intensity ultrasound beams can
accelerate natural clotting and stop bleeding.

results.content:
NEW TELESCOPES PAY OFF IN THE DETAILS 



   &UR;  &LR;  Astronomers in the 1990s are seeing the dawn of an
unprecedented golden age: New telescopes of a size and power
undreamed of just a few years ago are busting out all over,
promising to open the floodgates for a cascade of discoveries.


   Just last week, astronomers unveiled the ``first light'' images
of a new telescope that will survey the night skies to produce the
definitive roadmap of the heavens for decades to come. Two weeks
earlier, a new instrument prosaically called the Very Large
Telescope, whose makers say it is now the most powerful in the
world, produced its own dazzling ``first light'' pictures _ the
astronomers' term for the first usable astronomical images from a
new scope.


   Much more is on the way: While the venerable 200-inch Hale
telescope on Palomar Mountain reigned supreme for nearly four
decades, four new telescopes that surpass it have been completed
this decade, and at least a half-dozen more will join the ranks
over the next three years.


   Several factors have combined to make this remarkable telescopic
rennaissance possible: The dramatic and ever-growing power of
computers to control huge scopes with pinpoint precision using
smaller, simpler mountings, breakthrough concepts for making the
giant slabs of glass for telescope mirrors, and innovative
barn-like replacements for the unwieldy observatory domes of yore.


   The Very Large Telescope, built by a consortium of eight nations
known as the European Southern Observatory and installed on a
mountaintop called Cerro Paranal in the Chilean Andes, will
eventually consist of four identical linked telescopes. When
completed in two years, the four telescopes will be arrayed so that
their light can be combined, simulating one telescopic behemoth far
bigger than any telescope in existence or planned. (The Hubble
telescope, by contrast, gains its power to see fine detail by
escaping the atmosphere's turbulence; the scope itself is modest in
size, exceeded by no fewer than 30 telescopes around the world.)


   Even now, with just one of its telescopes completed, the Chilean
observatory reports that its first images demonstrate an ability to
detect fine details _ called ``resolving power'' _ that ``even at
this early stage, is unequalled by any large ground-based
telescope.''


   The telescope's main mirror is 8.2 meters, or about 27 feet, in
diameter _ making it the largest one-piece telescope mirror now in
service. It is unlike any of the other large telescope mirrors now
in use or being built: It is made of a thin sheet of glass glued
onto a honeycomb supporting structure. This unusual design makes it
flexible enough so that tiny computer-controlled devices can
constantly monitor and adjust its surface shape.


   Other large mirrors have either been assembled from an array of
hexagonal pieces fitted together like a tile floor, or cast in one
large solid piece to give them enough strength to hold their shape,
but with hollowed-out spaces in the back to lower their weight. The
VLT's innovative flexible mirrors may set a new standard for the
future.


   But size isn't everything. The Sloan Digital Sky survey uses a
new telescope whose mirror is neither exceptionally large (albeit
slightly bigger than Hubble's) nor unusual in design. But this new
telescope, based at Apache Point, N.M., is innovative in other
ways: A unique robotically-controlled system can move 640 optical
fibers so that each one aligns with a specific galaxy in the
scope's unusually wide field of view. That enables it to take
spectrograms _ spreading out the colors of the object's light to
reveal its chemical composition, distance and motion _ of hundreds
of galaxies at once.


   By the time it is completed, the telescope's survey will have
determined the distance and velocity of a million galaxies and
100,000 quasars _ far more than all the world's telescopes combined
have produced in the history of astronomy.


   The unusually sensitive and comprehensive coverage of this new
survey is expected to provide the photog

results.content:
NEW MEASUREMENT SUGGESTS UNIVERSE IS YOUNGER THAN BELIEVED 



   CHICAGO _ Using an array of radio telescopes stretching more
than 5,000 miles from Hawaii to the Virgin Islands, astronomers
have made what they say is the most accurate measurement ever of
the distance to a galaxy far beyond the Milky Way _ 23.5 million
light-years from here to a prominent galaxy in the constellation
Ursa Major, the Great Bear.


   Scientists said the measurement, announced here on Tuesday at a
meeting of the American Astronomical Society, raised serious
questions about the precision of recent estimates of the expansion
rate and age of the universe, including those reported last week by
astronomers using data from the Hubble Space Telescope.


   The new findings appeared to expose a possible shortcoming in
the basic galactic distances used in previous calculations of the
rate at which space and time are expanding from the explosive
moment of cosmic creation in the theoretical Big Bang. If the
galaxy measurement is correct, the universe is about 15 percent
smaller _ hence 15 percent younger _ than calculated on the basis
of the Hubble telescope data. That previous estimate put the age of
the universe at between 12 billion and 14 billion years old.


   ``We're questioning whether their ruler is really a foot long''
and not 10 or 11 inches, said Dr. James Moran, a member of the
radio astronomy team from the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for
Astrophysics in Cambridge, Mass.


   If cosmic distances have been measured inaccurately and the
universe is indeed younger than previously estimated, it would
cause consternation among cosmologists. Any age much less than 12
billion years would again raise the troubling paradox of a universe
seeming to be younger than its oldest stars.


   Dr. James Herrnstein of the National Radio Astronomy Observatory
in Socorro, N.M., who conducted most of the research, observed the
motion of gas orbiting the center of the galaxy NGC 4258, also
known as Messier 106. After first clocking the orbital velocity of
the gas and then measuring shifts in the positions of bright
water-vapor clouds in the gas, he applied high-school trigonometry
to calculate the distance to the galaxy _ and establish what may be
a more accurate scale for estimating cosmic distances.


   ``This is the most precise distance measured to a remote
galaxy,'' he said at a press conference on Tuesday. The discrepancy
between his results and previous distance scales, he added, ``is
statistically significant and it's very intriguing.''


   After hearing the report, Dr. Wendy L. Freedman of the Carnegie
Observatories in Pasadena, Calif., who led the Hubble telescope
team measuring the cosmic expansion rate, said the new technique
was ``a big step forward in distance measurements.''


   Dr. Freedman acknowledged, as she had in reporting her team's
results last week, that the largest uncertainty in her calculations
stemmed from extrapolating galactic distances based on distances to
the nearby Large Magellanic Cloud, which have been measured at
170,000 light-years away. This measurement was based primarily on
observations of Cepheid stars, objects of known intrinsic
luminosity that have acted as cosmic mileposts this century.


   But Dr. Freedman was not changing her expansion-rate estimates.
``I would be happier seeing half a dozen such galaxy measurements
before we say anything,'' she said.


   Members of Herrnstein's team said they might be able to make
similar measurements to two more galaxies in another year or two.
But finding candidate galaxies with favorable dynamic conditions
has not been easy. Of 700 galaxies studied, no more than 22 exhibit
the observable conditions required.


   For the measurements, astronomers used the Very Long Baseline
Array, a system of 10 identical dish-shaped 82-foot-diameter
antennas observing simultaneously and combining their data to give
them the viewing power equivalent to a 5,000-mile-wide telescope.
The array can thus produce detailed images of objects emitting
radiation in radio wavelengths. The central

results.content:
SECOND SIGHT  
 (FOR RELEASE THE WEEK OF JUNE 5, 2000)



   Astronomers and telescope builders have come up with a plan to
give the aging Hubble Space Telescope a new lease on life. Instead
of building an entirely new space telescope, they propose sending
up just huge mirrors, and then letting Hubble look through them.


   According to Jim Crocker of Johns Hopkins University in
Baltimore, a feasibility study has shown that it is possible to
turn the 2.4-meter Hubble into a giant 8-meter space observatory.


   ``The cost will be some $250 million,'' Crocker says, ``less
than half the cost of building a new space telescope.''


   The idea was proposed by Bob Woodruff of Ball Aerospace and
Roger Angel of the University of Arizona in Tucson. At first,
Crocker recalls, it sounded ``ridiculous.'' But a study group of
more than 20 engineers, set up by Crocker, found no obvious
show-stoppers.


   ``These people have a lot of experience with Hubble,'' Crocker
says. ``If they say it can be done, you can't dismiss that
easily.''


   An upgraded Hubble would be able to see planets orbiting nearby
stars _ currently these can only be detected indirectly _ and
search for signs of oxygen in their atmospheres. Also, with 10
times as much sensitivity and a fourfold improvement in resolution,
the new Hubble could peer back in space and time to the era before
the first galaxies were born.


   ``The science case is pretty compelling,'' Crocker says.


   To build the 8-meter telescope, the team proposes using a spare
mirror ``blank'' leftover from building the European Southern
Observatory's four-mirror Very Large Telescope. After polishing the
parabolic surface, the back would be ground away to leave a
meniscus-shaped mirror only 2 millimeters thick and weighing less
than 1 ton.


   Five thousand actuators on its back would control the shape of
the ultra-thin mirror. For launch, it would be cut in three, stowed
in the cargo bay of the space shuttle, and installed during a
number of spacewalks. Astronaut consultants say the job is
feasible, and the mirror could be launched as early as 2006.


   But in a recent report from the U.S. National Research Council
on astronomy priorities for the next decade, a review committee led
by Joe Taylor of Princeton University, N.J., and Chris McKee of the
University of California in Berkeley says it has ``not recommended
any new moderate or major missions for space-based ultraviolet or
optical astronomy for the coming decade.''


   The main reason is that infrared wavelengths offer greater
research opportunities and these wavelengths will be well covered
by the Next Generation Space Telescope, a $500 million observatory
with an 8-meter mirror due for launch in 2009 or 2010.


   ``The idea is very smart and the team that proposes it has to be
taken seriously,'' says Piero Benvenuti, director of the Space
Telescope European Coordiating Facility in Garching, Germany.
``But given the current budget situation, both in the United States
and Europe, I think it will remain an excellent and technically
extremely interesting academic exercise.'' &QL;


   &UR; (This article is excerpted from New Scientist, a weekly science
and technology magazine based in London.) &LR;  &QC;

results.content:
&HT;   



   AUSTIN, Texas _ University of Texas astronomer Fritz Benedict
has been studying NGC 4314, a spiral galaxy 40 million light years
from Earth, since 1980.


   Scientists study galaxies to learn about the life cycle of stars
because humanity depends on a star, the Sun. But, until this week,
Benedict had only seen NGC 4314 in the telescopes of UT's McDonald
Observatory: an interesting but fuzzy blob of faint yellow and
blue.


   On Thursday, NASA released the powerful Hubble space telescope's
first view of what NGC 4314 really is: a bright yellow jewel in a
setting of red and blue gems.The gems are a nursery where stars are
being born around the galaxy's yellow core.


   ``Lovely,'' said Benedict by e-mail from San Diego, Calif.,
where he was attending the summer meeting of the American
Astronomical Society, which will hold its winter meeting in Austin
in January. ``Not the most exciting picture, but certainly the best
looking.''


   The photo will be as useful as it is pretty, because it shows
the formation of stars with almost as much clarity as can be seen
in our own Milky Way galaxy.


   Unlike the Milky Way, increasingly visible with the unaided eye
at this time of year as a mass of luminous star clouds across the
eastern sky, NGC 4314 is too far away to see without a telescope.


   Benedict and other astronomers will use the Hubble picture and
additional Hubble data to modify computer models of star formation,
mathematical respresentations that aid their understanding. They
make the models, which predict a star's birth to death process,
because they won't live long enough to see the stars of any galaxy
change.


   ``The stars and gas do move,'' Benedict said. ``But it would
take thousands of years to see the motion.''


   Story Filed By Cox Newspapers


   For Use By Clients of the New York Times News Service

results.content:
1999-01-08 00:12:01 
 usa 
 Galaxy Estimates Have Increased 


	AUSTIN, Texas (AP) -- A long look deep into space by the Hubble  
Space Telescope has led astronomers to increase their estimate of 
the total number of galaxies in the universe. 


	In an experiment called the Hubble Deep Field South, the space  
telescope was focused on a small portion of the sky above the 
Southern Hemisphere for 10 days, taking images of galaxies out to 
about 11 billion light-years. 


	Based on the number of objects detected by the telescope,  
astronomers estimated that the universe contains about 125 billion 
galaxies. 


	In an earlier study, called the Hubble Deep Field North, the  
total number of galaxies was estimated at 80 billion. 


	Henry C. Ferguson of the Space Telescope Institute in Baltimore  
said the new estimate is higher because the space telescope has new 
instruments that allowed it to look farther than was possible in 
the first deep field study. 


	Because it could look deeper, he said, the telescope detected a  
greater density of galaxies. 


	Ferguson said the new study focused on an ordinary part of the  
sky over the Southern Hemisphere. The target was incredibly small, 
about the apparent size of a grain of sand held at arm's length. 


	But the telescope looked through some 11 billion light-years of  
space, exploiting the absolute limit of the telescope's keen 
vision. 


	The idea of the study was to capture a narrow beam sample of  
what the universe is like. It is rather like a core sample of the 
heavens. The images now will be studied by hundreds of astronomers 
worldwide. 


	The first deep field study by the Hubble resulted in dozens of  
new discoveries and increased a general understanding about the 
nature of the most distant part of the universe.

results.content:
HUBBLE DETECTS ANCIENT GALAXIES 



   The Hubble Space Telescope has succeeded in peering out through
space and back through time to find the oldest, most distant
galaxies ever seen. The discovery could lead to a better
understanding of the earliest formative stages of the universe,
astronomers said Thursday.


   ``This observation is a major step toward fulfilling one of
Hubble's key objectives: to search for the faintest and farthest
objects in the universe,'' said Edward Weiler, the National
Aeronautics and Space Administration's head of space science.


   The ancient galaxies apparently are being seen as they were when
the universe was only about one-20th of its present age, or much
less than a billion years old, the astronomers said at a briefing
at NASA headquarters in Washington. The previously most-distant
galaxies ever seen, which were observed by Hubble almost three
years ago using a different camera, were estimated to go back to
about one-10th of the universe's present age, or more than one
billion years after the universe's birth.


   The latest pictures were taken by a new camera installed on the
orbiting telescope early last year. Called NICMOS _ the
Near-Infrared Camera and Multi-Object Spectrometer _ the camera had
as one of its main purposes to be able to peer farther out into
space by picking up infrared radiation. That's because objects that
are farther from us are speeding away, and therefore have their
light shifted out of the visible range of light and into the
infrared, where human eyes can't see it.


   Thus, the new camera made it possible ``to extend Hubble's line
of sight farther out into the universe than we could any other
way,'' said David Leckrone, NASA's senior Hubble telescope
scientist. With the new observations, he said, ``that promise has
been fulfilled.''


   In the earlier Hubble picture of distant galaxies, called the
Hubble Deep Field, astronomers found that many of the oldest
galaxies they could see appeared to be small, fragmentary pieces
that lacked the symmetry and elegance of more recent spiral or
elliptical galaxies.


   But the new pictures reveal that at least some of the objects
that appeared to be galaxy fragments were simply the brightest
parts of normal-looking galaxies. The infrared pictures fill in the
blanks, connecting several of the fragments into a single, normal
spiral.


   ``Some of the images that looked like multiple, small galaxies
might be individual pieces of larger galaxies,'' said Lisa
Storrie-Lombardi of the Carnegie Institution in Pasadena.


   Although the most distant galaxies seen in the new picture are
too faint for the astronomers to be able to measure their exact
distances, about 10 of them appear to fit the expectations of what
the earliest, most distant galaxies should look like, said Rodger
Thompson, an astronomer at the University of Arizona and leader of
the team that made the observations.


   By continuing to analyze the details in this image, and perhaps
making follow-up observations of some of the newfound galaxies when
new, more powerful orbiting telescopes become available, Thompson
said, ``we can put together a much more complete scenario of how
our universe evolved.''


   Astronomers believe they have a good understanding of how the
universe as a whole formed in a great explosion called the Big
Bang, about 12 billion years ago, and also of how billions of
individual stars formed within each galaxy. But they do not yet
have a clear picture of how the galaxies themselves came into
being. Observations of the earliest stages of galaxy formation
could help them to figure out how that process worked.


   Alan Dressler, a Carnegie Institution astronomer and specialist
on galaxy formation, called the new observations ``an exciting
first step into the infrared view of the universe.'' The new
picture, he said, shows ``we were missing something'' in earlier
observations, and it is now clear that ``the universe was already
relatively well formed quite early on.''


   Leckrone said that while it will take more observations with

results.content:
COUNT OF GALAXIES SOARS IN HUBBLE-IMPROVED CENSUS



   AUSTIN, Texas _ Taking a census of the galaxies in the universe
is like counting the grains of sand on a beach. Even with leaping
extrapolations, the task is probably impossible, and the numbers
become, well, astronomical.


   Undaunted, astronomers studying new pictures taken by the Hubble
Space Telescope announced at a meeting of the American Astronomical
Society here Thursday an updated estimate of the number of galaxies
in the observable universe: 125 billion. As recently as three years
ago, the count was only 50 billion, which was subsequently raised
to 80 billion.


   The new figure reflects not a spurt in galactic births, of
course, but instead an improvement in the Hubble telescope's
ability to peer deep into the universe, back closer to the first
epoch in which matter coalesced into stars and stars congregated in
vast galaxies. The new observations have detected some faint
galaxies so far away that they were probably formed when the
universe was no more than 1 billion years old, less than 10 percent
of its current estimated age of some 13 billion years.


   Dr. Henry Ferguson, an astronomer at the Space Telescope Science
Institute in Baltimore, said the new galaxy estimate was derived
from the Hubble telescope's observations of a small patch of
southern sky taken over a 10-day period in October. The pictures,
called the Hubble Deep Field South, were a sequel to a similar
survey of a part of the northern sky made in late 1995.


   The southern survey was able to get a deeper cosmic view because
of two new instruments that had been added to the Hubble telescope.
One is a camera for recording objects seen in near-infrared light;
it can detect galaxies otherwise obscured by dust. The other
instrument was an imaging spectrograph that produced some of the
deepest optical pictures ever taken.


   The photographs revealed galaxies of all sizes and shapes in a
narrow corridor of the sky, reaching back some 12 billion years.
Astronomers counted 620 galaxies there. The previous survey, which
covered a larger section of the northern sky, showed more than
3,000 galaxies. From these numbers, the Hubble astronomers
extrapolated a total galaxy population of 125 billion.


   Ferguson said the count came as no surprise, because other
evidence indicates that star and galaxy formation was particularly
rampant in the early universe.


   Astronomers expect the findings to help refine models of galaxy
formation and evolution through time. And their field of study just
expanded, inasmuch as each large galaxy comprises perhaps a billion
stars.

results.content:
1999-04-16 
 Hubble Captures Most Distant Object in Universe 


LONDON, April 15 (Xinhua) -- U.S. scientists using the Hubble
Space Telescope have discovered the oldest and most distant known
object in the Universe.


The object, a galaxy of new stars, is 13 billion light-years
away from Earth, a distance corresponds to when the Universe was
only 5 percent of its present age.


Professor Kenneth Lanzetta and colleagues from the State
University of New York at Stony Brook, made the discovery using
the Space Telescope Imaging Spectrograph aboard Hubble.


This instrument enables them to study the light from very faint
objects, which is invisible to conventional telescopes.


Their results, published Thursday in the British science
journal Nature, showed the object is a galaxy broadcasting
particularly strongly in the ultraviolet part of the spectrum,
suggesting star formation of particularly youthful vigor.


Scientists said that the new finding can help them determine
when galaxies formed and developed, and learn more about the
origins of the chemical elements that make life possible.


They believed that as technology available to astronomers would
gradually improve, there would undoubtedly be further discoveries
of objects even further away in space than the galaxy just
identified.

results.content:
1997-02-11 
 Upgraded Hubble to Probe Deeper Into Universe 


WASHINGTON, February 11 (Xinhua) -- The Hubble Space Telescope,
one of the finest tools of Big Science, awaits a servicing call
this week for the installation of advanced instruments which will
open a new window on the universe.


Aboard shuttle Discovery, which blasted off early this morning
with seven crew members, there are two instruments. One is the
100-million-dollar Near-Infrared Camera and Multi-Object
Spectrometer (NICMOS), and the other, a 120-million-dollar Space
Telescope Imaging Spectrograph (STIS).


After replacing older science instruments with the above two,
the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) expected
to look farther back in space and time with the Hubble than ever
before, and have a more powerful tool in the search for black
holes, planets and details of galaxies and stars.


Experts said it was possible to look back to the epoch of
galaxy formation, less than one billion years after the Big Bang,
with the new instruments.


According to NASA's schedule, following a two-day orbital
chase, Discovery will approach the telescope from directly below,
using a rendezvous procedure developed for docking with the
Russian Mir Space Station.


If everything goes well, the astronauts will use a robot arm to
pluck the Hubble at 2:52 a.m. Thursday, and mount it vertically on
a service platform in Discovery's cargo bay.


In four space-walks, the astronauts will install the 765-pound
NICMOS and the 700-pound STIS in place of old hardware, and then
replace computer equipment, data recorders and other ageing
electrical and mechanical components of the telescope.


They are expected to release the upgraded Hubble back into open
space at 12:42 a.m. on February 18. Then engineers on the ground
will begin to check out and calibrate the new instruments.

1997-05-13 
 Major News Items in Leading U.S. Newspapers 


WASHINGTON, May 13 (Xinhua) -- The following are major news
items in leading U.S. newspapers today:


The New York Times:


-- For the first time in eight years, the Prime Ministers of
India and Pakistan met and held direct talks. Both called for
cuts in the military spending they described as ruinous for
their countries.


-- Russian President Yeltsin signed a peace treaty with his
Chechen counterpart, Aslan Maskhadov. Russia continued to insist
that Chechnya is formally part of the Russian federation and
pledged never to use or threaten to use force in relations with
Chechnya.


The Washington Post:


-- NASA released the first returns from the upgraded Hubble
Space Telescope Monday. The scientists predicted that the new,
improved Hubble will soon eclipse the old one's achievements.


-- Opposition members of Mexico's Congress called on the ruling
party Monday to reopen a legislative probe into a government
agency reported to be under investigation on suspicion it was used
for drug trafficking and money laundering.


The Wall Street Journal:


-- The White House asked the Supreme Court to overturn a court
decision ordering administration lawyers to give the Whitewater
prosecutor notes of interviews with Hillary Clinton.

results.content:
1997-02-21 
 Discovery Returns from Successful Hubble Service 


WASHINGTON, February 21 (Xinhua) -- U.S. space shuttle
Discovery returned home early this morning after astronauts
successfully ended their 10-day Hubble Space telescope service
mission.


Discovery touched down on the runway of Kennedy Space Center,
Florida, at 3:32 a.m. EST under an almost full moon after passing
the first landing chance one and a half hours earlier because of
scattered clouds. The landing before dawn this morning is only the
ninth in darkness in total 82 space shuttle flights.


During their 10-day space voyage, the astronauts equipped the
Hubble telescope through four spacewalks with a new powerful
infrared camera and an advanced spectrograph as well as new
electronics, data recorders and some mechanical components. They
also repaired peeling thermal insulation on the telescope in the
unplanned fifth spacewalk.


The $795 million mission was the second of at least four service
calls planned for Hubble, which is near halfway through its 15-year
voyage. Hubble will be equipped with a more advanced camera during
astronauts' next visit in late 1999.

results.content:
SATELLITE OBSERVATORY TO EXPAND KNOWLEDGE OF UNIVERSE 



   CAMBRIDGE, Mass. _ A new satellite observatory called Chandra,
poised for a launch aboard the space shuttle Columbia early Tuesday
morning, is expected to do for the violent, mysterious world of
X-ray astronomy what the Hubble telescope did for the visible sky:
open up a new universe of discoveries by lofting its unprecedented
power far above Earth's soupy atmosphere.


   And in a significant first, the $2.7 billion project was
designed and managed, and will be controlled throughout its
lifetime of at least five years in orbit, by scientists and
engineers at the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory in
Cambridge.


   The actual control and testing of the satellite will be managed
at a new control center, while the processing of all the data that
will be sent back from the observatory, and the evaluation and
scheduling of requests for observing time from astronomers around
the world, will take place at a new science center at the Harvard
Observatory.


   After more than a decade of work to design and oversee
construction of the 45-foot long, 5-ton spacecraft, activity among
the Chandra team in Cambridge, and at Cape Canaveral for the
launch, was at a fever pitch as the long-awaited takeoff _ delayed
since last summer by a series of technical problems _ finally drew
near. The project has been in the works since the mid-1970s.


   ``It's been a long road,'' said Chandra program manager Fred S.
Wojtalik. The Chandra telescope, named in honor of India-born
astrophysicist Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar, is ``the baby of quite a
few people who have devoted significant parts of a lifetime to
making this happen,'' he said.


   The shuttle Columbia was to roar into orbit at 12:36 a.m. with
Eileen Collins at the controls, the first woman astronaut named
commander of a shuttle mission. Collins, who will be flying with
the heaviest, most expensive cargo ever carried by the shuttle (at
least, in unclassified flights), has flown twice before as pilot,
the No. 2 position.


   This morning, about seven hours after liftoff, a delicate series
of maneuvers will begin positioning the tractor-trailer-sized
telescope for release from the shuttle's payload bay. After
release, as soon as radio communication with the spacecraft is
established, control of the observatory will shift from Houston to
Cambridge.


   The telescope will go through some last-minute tests, and then
late Wednesday it will be launched into a higher, oval orbit by
firing its attached rocket motor.


   Once in its higher orbit _ which will reach out as far as 87,000
miles above Earth, or a third of the way to the moon, at its
highest point _ the telescope will be out of reach of astronauts.
Even at the low point in its 64-hour orbit, Chandra will be 6,200
miles high _ more than 20 times the shuttle's maximum altitude.


   The Hubble telescope, by contrast, was designed from the start
to be serviced and have its various cameras replaced by shuttle
astronauts. This capability proved crucial when it was discovered
soon after launch that Hubble's main telescope mirror had been made
in the wrong shape, preventing the telescope from focusing
properly. The error was fixed by special corrective mirrors
installed on a later shuttle mission.


   Because there will be no second chances this time, Wojtalik
said, testing was crucial.


   ``Every test we could think of has been completed and completed
well,'' he said. ``We've done things far beyond what I would say
was normal,'' including having five separate committees check out
all the plans.


   Once in operation, the telescope will provide views of X-rays
given off by objects as close as the planets of our own solar
system, and as distant as the furthest quasars at the fringes of
the universe. Its images of these distant objects will be 10 times
more detailed, and it will be able to detect objects up to 100
times fainter, than any previous X-ray telescope.


   Chandra is expected to provide new information about black
holes, colliding galaxies, exploding stars, an

results.content:
1999-01-09 
 Astronomers: Universe May Contain 125 Billion Galaxies 


WASHINGTON, January 8 (Xinhua) -- U.S. astronomers said that
the universe may contain about 125 billion galaxies.


The astronomers made such an estimate based on the
observations by the Hubble Space Telescope, the Associated Press
reported Friday.


In a study "the Hubble Deep Field South", the space telescope
was focused on a small portion of the sky above the Southern
Hemisphere for 10 days and took images of galaxies 11 billion
light-years away.


An earlier study "Hubble Deep Field North" estimated the total
number of galaxies are 80 billions.


Henry C. Ferguson of the Space Telescope Institute in
Baltimore said the new estimate is higher because the space
telescope has new instruments that allowed it to look farther
than before.


Astronomers said that the study is aimed at capturing a narrow
beam sample of what the universe is like.


It is just like a core sample of the heavens. The images taken
this time will be studied by astronomers throughout the world,
the report said.

results.content:
ASTRONOMERS URGED TO FOLLOW THEIR STARS 



   CHICAGO _ The head of the National Aeronautics and Space
Administration has a message for the country's astronomers: stop
hugging the Hubble Space Telescope.


   Daniel S. Goldin, the NASA administrator, certainly meant no
disrespect for the orbiting telescope, regarded by many as the most
successful space project of the decade. Its spectacular pictures
and revealing data from the depths of the universe have stretched
the dimensions of wonder for scientists and the public alike. And
it is still going strong.


   Instead, in a June 3 speech to a national meeting of the
American Astronomical Society here, Goldin was exhorting scientists
to think expansively and identify new technologies for spacecraft
and telescopes needed for understanding more about the composition,
evolution, structure and origin of the universe. He called on them
to recommend ``visionary goals that will resonate, that will
excite, that will carry humanity far, far into the future.''


   While he made no specific proposals or immediate promises of
increased spending, Goldin offered some ideas to illustrate the
scope of thinking he had in mind. He challenged scientists to
conceive of new techniques to search for life on Earthlike planets
around other stars, and durable, low-cost propulsion systems
capable of sending robots there. He imagined robots the size of
soft-drink cans with software systems mimicking biological
processes, which would be able to adapt to and deal with
unanticipated problems and thus evolve into ``intelligent
interstellar probes.''


   Goldin also spoke of deploying into deep space ``gossamer
telescopes'' with mirrors several hundred feet wide (Hubble's is
less than 8 feet) and arrays of widely separated telescopes capable
of coordinated observations for even sharper images of the cosmos.
Other space probes might be able to measure gravitational radiation
from the first microseconds of the universe's creation in the
theorized Big Bang. One might even be sent to hover over and obtain
direct images of the consuming gravitational forces at regions
known as black holes.


   The audience of senior astronomers as well as graduate students
just starting their careers broke into laughter when Goldin,
driving home his anticomplacency message, said, ``Too many of you
are hugging the Hubble Space Telescope.''


   It was the knowing laughter that comes from hearing a truth
exposed. Because of years of budget constraints, astronomers said
later, those in the field had stopped dreaming and were clinging to
what they had, dwelling on ways to keep the Hubble operating longer
or developing a larger version, called the Next Generation Space
Telescope, for launching in the next decade. The Hubble, deployed
in 1991, was designed to have a 15-year lifetime.


   ``He's telling us it's OK to dream again,'' said Dr. Michael S.
Turner, University of Chicago astrophysicist.


   Some astronomers expressed skepticism. Where's the money? How
can we dream if we do not have something now to live on and work
with? Where are specific plans or new institutional frameworks for
transforming dreams into reality?


   Such reservations might have been more widespread if the call to
dream again had come from anyone other than Goldin. Since he became
NASA administrator in 1992, he has shaken and stirred the agency
more than any previous leader in the period after the Apollo
lunar-landing project of the 1960s.


   Dr. Robert Gehrz of the University of Minnesota, the president
of the astronomical society, said Goldin ``has been widely
praised'' for reviving and streamlining the planetary exploration
program and then establishing a new effort, called the Origins
Program, bringing together biologists, astronomers, and planetary
scientists to study the newly discovered extrasolar planetary
systems for evidence of life.


   To save a moribund planetary program, Goldin introduced a new
design philosophy of ``faster, cheaper, better'' missions,
replacing the past reliance on expensive, multi-purpose spacecraft.
These mis

results.content:
HUBBLE OFFERS GLIMPSE INTO DAWN OF THE UNIVERSE



   Peering farther back in space and time than ever before, the
Hubble Space Telescope has taken infrared pictures of what may be
the most distant objects ever detected, early light from the
galactic dawn of the universe.


   Astronomers are not sure, but they think some of the faint
objects could be galaxies formed in the first billion years of
cosmic history, or more than 12 billion years ago. If so, they are
crossing a new frontier of the cosmos, where they hope to find the
very first galaxies and solve the mystery of when and how such
congregations of stars emerged out of the formless dark.


   ``These images are the deepest images of distant galaxies that
have ever been obtained,'' Rodger Thompson, a University of Arizona
astronomer, said in announcing the new Hubble telescope findings
Thursday.


   Alan Dressler, an astronomer with the Carnegie Observatories in
Pasadena, Calif., agreed that the infrared pictures were ``our
first tentative glimpse into the very remote universe.''


   Although these may represent ``the first stages of galaxy
formation,'' Dressler said, the objects are such faint blobs that
``their true nature can only be explored with the advanced
telescopes of the future.'' He was referring, in particular, to the
more powerful replacement for the Earth-orbiting Hubble telescope
that is being planned for launching in 2007.


   The National Aeronautics and Space Administration made the
infrared pictures public Thursday at a news conference in
Washington. A catalog of the observed objects and other research
details will be published soon in The Astronomical Journal.


   In January, using its infrared spectrometer-camera, an
instrument installed by visiting astronauts in early 1997, the
telescope took a 36-hour exposure of a relatively narrow region of
space that had previously been examined in visible and ultraviolet
light. Three years ago, when the Hubble telescope took a 10-day
exposure with its visible-light camera of the same field of view,
astronomers found hundreds of galaxies that had never been seen
before, inspiring them to raise their estimate of the total number
of galaxies in the observable universe to more than 50 billion from
10 billion. The Hubble Deep Field, as the visible photography was
known, had been until now the deepest view of galaxies.


   Cameras sensitive to infrared wavelengths can often penetrate
the dust that obscures many of the most distant cosmic phenomena.
Some of these objects are so far away that their only detectable
light is in the infrared wavelengths. Most galaxies radiate more
infrared light than visible light.


   The more than 300 galaxies in the main infrared picture included
some that had been seen before. But the infrared camera revealed
many new objects, the reddest and faintest of which may be the
earliest galaxies ever detected. Astronomers said the distant
galaxies seemed to be smaller than those from more recent epochs.
But they said it was not yet possible to determine if the galaxies
were truly small or whether these were merely the cores of larger
structures that could not be seen at these distances.


   Thompson, the principal scientist working with the infrared
instrument's observations, estimated that the most-distant objects
in the picture dated back to when the universe was 5 percent of its
present age. That age is still a matter of debate, but some of the
most recent data and theoretical models indicate that the universe
began about 13 billion years ago.


   ``The fact that we have found new objects means we really have
reached the edge'' of the universe, Thompson said. That is, the
observations take astronomers close to the time when matter in the
early universe first coalesced into stars and the stars clustered
in galaxies. How this happened is one of the great unknowns of
astronomy.


   In analyzing the results, Thompson also found that faint red
galaxies matched up with compact blue knots of light that had been
seen in the earlier visible photography of the region.


   ``This

1999-06-01 16:00:11 
 washington 
 NASA Measure of Universe Questioned 


	CHICAGO (AP) -- A new method of measuring distances to far  
galaxies casts doubt about the proclamation last week by NASA 
astronomers that they had determined the age and expansion rate of 
the universe. 


	A technique using a radio-telescope is a ``golden ruler'' for  
measuring cosmic distances and calls into question the conclusions 
announced by astronomers using the Hubble Space Telescope who were 
supported by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, a 
researcher said Tuesday. 


	``Ours is a direct measurement, using geometry, and is  
independent of all other methods of determining cosmic distances,'' 
said Jim Herrnstein of the National Radio Astronomy Observatory. 
``It is the most precise distance ever measured to a remote 
galaxy.'' 


	Herrnstein presented his findings Tuesday at the national  
meeting of the American Astronomical Society. 


	He said the new technique shows a 15 to 20 percent margin of  
error in the results announced last week by a NASA team led by 
Wendy Freedman of the Carnegie Institute of Washington. 


	The NASA team using the space telescope said last week that it  
had successfully achieved the goal of measuring within an 
uncertainty of only 10 percent the speed at which the universe is 
expanding, a value called the Hubble constant. 


	Based on its study, the team concluded that the universe is 12  
to 13 billion years old and is expanding at an accelerating rate of 
70 kilometers per second for every 3.3 million light years in 
distance from the Earth. 


	Herrnstein said this calculation is off by 15 to 20 percent. He  
based his conclusion on the difference in calculated distance to a 
specific galaxy using his technique compared with the calculation 
method used by the NASA group. 


	Freedman and her group of 27 astronomers funded by NASA spent  
eight years measuring the distance to stars that pulsate in 
brightness at a known rate. Such stars, called Cepheids, are 
considered ``standard candles'' whose varying luminosity gives a 
gauge for their distance. 


	But Herrnstein said the technique using Cepheids is far less  
accurate than his new method that directly measures the motion of 
gas around a galaxy. 


	Herrnstein used a galaxy called NGC 4258 to establish what he  
called a ``golden ruler'' for measuring cosmic distances. 


	NGC 4258 is surrounded by a rotating cloud of gas. Within this  
gas cloud is water vapor, which tends to amplify radio signals. 
This creates radio ``hot spots'' called masers. 


	The orbital speed of masers between NGC 4258 and Earth was  
measured in 1994, and again every few months over the following 
three years. By determining the speed at which the masers were 
moving, the astronomers created a triangle with the first maser 
position at one angle, the latest position at a second angle, and 
the galaxy center at the third angle. Measuring the angles gives 
the distance. 


	``We can use plain old trigonometry to calculate the distance,''  
said Lincoln Greenhill, a member of the Herrnstein team. 


	``It is very simple and direct,'' said Herrnstein. ``Most of us  
know enough math from high school to do the calculation.'' 


	The distance to NGC 4258 was calculated at 23.5 million light  
years, with an accuracy to within 4 percent. This distance has been 
calculated using the Cepheid star technique at 27 to 29 million 
light years. 


	Herrnstein said that the distance measure using Cepheid stars is  
based on a series of assumed values, such as the distance to the 
Large Magellanic Cloud, a galaxy neighbor to the Milky Way. These 
assumed values, said Herrnstein, have a greater margin of error 
than does the direct measuring technique he is using. 


	Freedman, who attended a news conference at which Herrnstein  
announced his results, said the new study provided ``wonderful 
data,'' but she would like other measurements to be taken to 
confirm its accuracy. 


	Also, she said the assumed values used in the Cepheid star  
technique have been

results.content:
&HT;   



   WASHINGTON _ Of several technological breakthroughs that helped
revolutionize modern astronomy, two events in the 1990s stand out.


   The first was the launching of NASA's Hubble Space Telescope in
April 1990. Initially nearsighted because of a design error, the
Hubble was repaired when a pair of space shuttle astronauts
installed a corrective lens.


   Since then, the city bus-sized telescope has radioed to Earth
more than 259,000 images, ranging from the surface of the moon to
deep space objects.


   The images astonished astronomers with their clarity and
revealed heavenly details that have rewritten many astronomical
disciplines.


   The second innovation was a spin-off of former President
Reagan's ``Star Wars'' dream, the Strategic Defense Initiative
(SDI).


   In order to guide the program's huge ground-based lasers, which
SDI planners hoped would one day zap enemy missiles out of the sky,
Air Force scientists set out to find a way to overcome the
distortions the atmosphere imposes on ground-based observations of
space.


   These distortions, caused by the fact that the air is not a
uniform fluid but contains areas of varying density, had plagued
astronomers for centuries. In fact, the problem was a prime
justification for launching the Hubble.


   One astronomer said studying a ``twinkling'' star through
Earth's atmosphere was like looking at something ``through a
fishbowl that someone is stirring.''


   The solution was a laser beam aimed at the stratosphere, where
it reflected off a layer of sodium molecules and came back to
Earth. The distortion imposed on the reflected beam could be
measured and compensated for.


   The technique was declassified by the Air Force in 1991 and made
public the following day by Dayton, Ohio, native Robert Fugate at a
meeting of the American Astronomical Society.


   It is now used to control precise adjustments that can be made
to thin, flexible telescope mirrors in order to correct for
atmospheric distortion. It made possible a new generation of
ground-based telescopes that rival the Hubble in the precision of
their imagery.


   Jeff Nesmith's e-mail address is jeffn(at)coxnews.com.


   ENDIT


   Story Filed By Cox Newspapers


   For Use By Clients of the New York Times News Service

results.content:
HUBBLE'S INFRARED PICTURE SHOW: HOW STARS ARE BORN 



   Before its infrared camera shut down in November, the Hubble
Space Telescope focused on an assortment of spiral galaxies for
some of its last pictures in those invisible wavelengths, giving
astronomers penetrating looks through thick galactic dust into the
glowing hydrogen clouds where stars are being born.


   Dr. Torsten Boeker, an astronomer at the Space Telescope Science
Institute in Baltimore, said the pictures, part of the telescope's
concentrated study of about 100 nearby spiral galaxies, were
particularly useful for investigating the dynamics of
star-formation regions. In visible light, many of these regions are
hidden from view by the very clouds of gas and dust enveloping
them.


   The telescope's other camera and instruments are still operating
normally, but its near-infrared camera and multi-object
spectrometer, a single instrument, ran out of coolant and had to be
switched off.


   In a service mission scheduled in October, space shuttle
astronauts are to visit the orbiting observatory to install an
improved computer and new set of gyroscopes for stabilizing the
telescope. It will be at least another year before a second shuttle
mission can restore the infrared camera with a new cooling system.


   Describing the new pictures, Boeker said that an effort was made
to snap spiral galaxies at all angles, from the classic face-on
view of NGC 5653 to the edge-on shot of NGC 891. Other pictures
showed close-ups of the hubs of galaxies glowing in white light
from the dense concentration of stars.


   For all the pictures, filters introduced false colors to
highlight textures and material recorded in infrared wavelengths
that would otherwise be invisible to the human eye. Red, for
example, corresponds to glowing hydrogen, the raw material of star
birth. Blue represents the main galactic structure of spiral arms
composed of young and middle-aged stars. Green is a mixture of the
red and blue images. The galaxy cores are mostly white because of
their concentrations of stars.


   In most cases, astronomers said, red knots in the spiral arms
pinpointed rich star-forming regions. But the glowing hydrogen
inside the galactic cores, they said, could have several possible
explanations. They could reveal star birth or the radiation from
the vicinity of massive black holes, or a combination of both.


   Though galaxies come in many other shapes, like ellipticals and
dwarfs, Boeker said that esthetics largely dictated the Hubble's
picture selection. ``Spirals,'' he said, ``are more beautiful.''

results.content:
SCIENTISTS UNVEIL A DARING VISION OF TOOLS TO PROBE SPACE



   Ten years from now, astronomers will have seen the first
glimmerings of light as stars and galaxies coalesced in the gloom
of the early universe, observed how the powerful gravity of a black
hole warped the very fabric of space, and perhaps searched for
signs of life in the glow of blue planets like Earth as they
circled nearby stars.


   That sweeping, and expensive, vision for astronomical discovery
over the next decade is described by an influential panel of
scientists in ``Astronomy and Astrophysics in the New Millennium,''
a report released on Thursday by the National Academy of Sciences.
Often referred to as the decadal survey, the report is one of a
series issued every 10 years by astronomers, giving their
priorities and hopes for new observing instruments.


   In the past, the survey has wielded great influence on the
roster of instruments that were built. The co-chairmen of the
committee that wrote the new report are Joseph H. Taylor Jr., a
Princeton University astrophysicist and Nobel laureate, and
Christopher F. McKee, an astrophysicist at the University of
California, Berkeley.


   At the top of this year's list is an audacious successor to the
orbiting Hubble Space Telescope that would be 100 to 600 times as
sensitive, two to three times as large, and able to look far more
deeply into the low-energy radiation, called the infrared, that
arrives from the young, star-forming universe. Close behind are a
giant, ground-based telescope with an eye 100 feet across and a
fleet of four large spaceborne telescopes working in concert to
discover Earth-like planets.


   With a minimum cost of $4.7 billion for instruments that would
require a wide range of new technologies, the recommendations are
nothing if not daring for fields as abstract as astronomy,
astrophysics and cosmology.


   Assuming that most of those instruments are built, ``we are in a
position to ask, `How did the universe begin? How did it evolve
from a soup of elementary particles into the structures that we see
today? Is there life elsewhere in the universe?''' said Dr. Michael
Turner, chairman of the astronomy and astrophysics department at
the University of Chicago and a member of the committee that wrote
that report.


   Dr. Anneila Sargent, another committee member, who is a
professor of astronomy at the California Institute of Technology
and director of the Owens Valley Radio Observatory, said the impact
of many of the discoveries envisioned in the report would be great
enough to be felt beyond the narrow community of scientists.


   ``Everybody, across the spectrum, would agree that if we could
find a planet that could support life like on Earth, we would be
stunned,'' Sargent said. ``It would be the kind of thing that would
change our philosophy of the world.''


   Writers of the report also had their eye on the cost.


   ``I think we've done the best job we can at setting a number
that we can live with,'' Taylor said.


   A congressional staff member who is knowledgeable about science
issues said that because the panel members ``do the heavy lifting
of actually trying to prioritize,'' the report has had much
influence in garnering support for programs in the past.


   The survey has also traditionally been well-received at crucial
agencies like NASA and the National Science Foundation, a fact that
should help boost the prospects of the panel's big winner, the Next
Generation Space Telescope, or NGST.


   ``The first thing it says to me is their top priority is my top
priority, which is NGST,'' said Dr. Anne Kinney, program director
for the Astronomical Search for Origins at NASA's Office of Space
Science. ``It really helps to hear that that is the number one
priority of this extremely distinguished group of astronomers.''


   The telescope, which Kinney said could be launched by the end of
the decade, would cost roughly a billion dollars and involve
gossamer-like materials that would fold up on launch and be
unfurled to create a mirror perhaps 20 feet across once th

results.content:
A NEW BABY PICTURE OF THE SOUTHERN SKY 



   Borrowing an exploratory technique from geology, astronomers
have learned to take ``core samples,'' not of Earth but of the
great depths of time in the universe. In 1995, astronomers aimed
the Hubble Space Telescope for 10 days of concentrated observations
of a single patch of the northern sky.


   The long camera exposures, in effect, bored through space and
time to produce views filled with thousands of galaxies at various
ages and stages of evolution, some appearing as they existed when
the universe was only 10 percent of its current age.


   Now comes the sequel, a core sample of the southern sky that
gives astronomers more spectacular views of galaxies never before
seen and probably new clues to the history of the universe.


   Over a similar 10-day period last month, the Hubble telescope
operated by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration was
focused on a narrow region in the constellation Tucana, near the
south celestial pole. The pictures, called the Hubble Deep Field
South, were made available Monday to astronomers.


   ``The southern field promises to be the most studied area of the
sky over the next five years,'' said Dr. Robert Williams, the
astronomer at the Space Telescope Science Institute in Baltimore
who led the observations.


   A team of 50 astronomers and data processors has conducted a
preliminary examination of the pictures and concluded that they
appear to validate the common assumption that the universe looks
largely the same in any direction.


   Powerful new telescopes in Australia and Chile will be trained
on the galaxies revealed by the survey and will precisely measure
their distances from Earth and other properties.


   The first findings based on the new observations in ultraviolet,
optical and infrared light are expected to be reported in January
at a meeting of the American Astronomical Society in Austin, Texas.


   At first glance, Williams said, astronomers noted that
disk-shaped galaxies seemed to be more common in the southern
survey than in the northern one, and elliptical galaxies less
common. Astronomers said that some of the more spectacular objects,
with variegated patterns like marbles, could be two or more
galaxies at different distances superimposed on each other. Or,
they could be examples of merging galaxies.


   The results have raised expectations. The importance of mergers
in the evolution of galaxies was one of the insights gained from
the northern study. Another insight was that galaxies appeared to
develop from the bottom up, not the top down.


   That is, they begin as smaller objects, which are prevalent in
the early universe, and grow into larger galaxies and groups of
galaxies, instead of extraordinarily large structures that break
into galaxies.


   The survey also showed that star formation seemed to peak seven
billion to nine billion years ago, consistent with earlier studies
of the composition of the intergalactic medium.


   Williams said the most significant result of the northern survey
was the validation of a technique of using the colors of galaxies,
as seen through different filters, to estimate their distances from
Earth. The technique is proving useful in estimating distances of
galaxies beyond the range of ground-based telescopes.


   The target region for the southern observations was selected
because it incorporated one phenomenon, a quasar, not present in
the northern survey. Quasars are extremely distant and bright
objects believed to be powered by black holes, those gravitational
sinks at the cores of many galaxies.


   Quasars are like beacons shining through cosmic haze. Because
they are usually so far away, their light travels through and
illuminates otherwise invisible clouds of intervening hydrogen gas.


   The Hubble's imaging spectrograph was used to dissect light from
this quasar and thus detect some of the universe's hidden structure
between the galaxies and over the billions of light-years between
Earth and the quasar.


   Properties of the quasar light should not

results.content:
1999-01-20 13:46:50 
 usa 
 NASA Launch of X-ray Scope Delayed 


	CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (AP) -- NASA's newest and most powerful  
X-ray telescope has been grounded for weeks and perhaps months 
because of bad circuit boards. 


	The Chandra X-ray Observatory was to have soared aboard space  
shuttle Columbia on April 8. Now it won't fly until mid-May or even 
summer, NASA said Wednesday, a delay that will add millions of 
dollars to the $1.5 billion project. 


	The flawed circuit boards are in the telescope's crucial command  
and data unit and must be replaced. Copper plating needed for 
electrical conductivity somehow came off. 


	It's the latest in a series of setbacks for the X-ray telescope,  
a Hubble-caliber instrument that should have rocketed into orbit 
last summer but was hampered by software trouble and other 
problems. 


	NASA is being extra cautious with Chandra for fear of another  
Hubble-type debacle. The Hubble Space Telescope was launched in 
1990 with a defective mirror that had to be fixed by spacewalking 
astronauts. 


	``To us, failure is not an option,'' said Kenneth Ledbetter,  
director of development for NASA's space science office. ``Unlike 
Hubble, it's not serviceable. It goes into a very high orbit and 
will not be reachable with the shuttle.'' 


	Chandra, in development since the 1970s, is meant to detect  
faint sources of cosmic X-rays, such as quasars, exploded stars and 
possibly black holes. 


	For now, NASA has delayed the launch by five weeks to May 13,  
the same day Discovery is supposed to lift off with equipment for 
the new international space station. NASA said it's too soon to 
know which flight will go first. 


	The telescope's 129 circuit boards which were made by an  
Albuquerque, N.M., company that has since been acquired by BF 
Goodrich. So far, at least two boards are believed to have 
problems. At worst, 22 boards will need to be replaced, which could 
mean a delay of several months, Ledbetter said. 


	The telescope-delivery flight will be the first NASA mission  
commanded by a woman, Eileen Collins.

results.content:
1999-04-14 22:42:26 
 usa 
 Hubble Finds Most Distant Galaxy 


	It is the oldest, most distant object ever detected -- a galaxy  
full of new stars, 13 billion light-years from Earth. Its 
discoverers have dubbed it ``Sharon.'' 


	The galaxy found by astronomers using the Hubble Space Telescope  
lies near the edge of the universe. Its presence was detected by 
its faint ultraviolet light, which is invisible to conventional 
telescopes. 


	Paradoxically, the oldest known galaxy -- named after the sister  
of one of its discoverers -- appears young to us. 


	That's because the deeper astronomers look into space, the  
further back in time they are looking. It takes so long for light 
traveling through space to reach Earth that astronomers scanning 
the edges of the universe are seeing objects as they were billions 
of years ago. 


	By some estimates, we are seeing the galaxy as it existed 1  
billion years after the Big Bang, the colossal explosion believed 
to have created the universe. 


	The discovery by researchers at the State University of New York  
at Stony Brook was reported in today's issue of the journal Nature. 
It is the third time in the past year that astronomers have found 
what were thought to be the most distant objects yet. 


	Other astronomers said the finding can help them determine when  
galaxies formed and developed, and learn more about the origins of 
the chemical elements that make life possible. 


	``Finding the most distant galaxies is akin to finding the  
oldest fossils on Earth,'' said Patrick McCarthy of the Carnegie 
Institution Observatories in Pasadena, Calif. ``They give you a 
handle on the timing and processes by which the first recognizable 
galaxies coalesced from the primordial sea of light elements.'' 


	Galaxies appear to come in two basic designs -- disc-shaped  
spiral galaxies like the Milky Way, and more massive, elliptical 
galaxies. But the SUNY researchers said their target is much too 
far away even for the Hubble to see clearly, so they can't say what 
type it might be. 


	``It's really not interesting to look at,'' said Kenneth  
Lanzetta, co-author of the Nature study. ``There is no detail to be 
seen.'' 


	In fact, the new galaxy is so faint that some astronomers said  
they might have to wait until better instruments are developed to 
learn something from it. Richard Green of the Kitt Peak National 
Observatory in Tucson, Ariz., said the discovery is ``at the limit 
of our grasp.'' 


	Until recently, records for the most distant objects in space  
stood for years. But sensitive detectors on the Hubble and large 
ground-based telescopes are capturing the faintest light from the 
most distant neighborhoods of the cosmos, and the record books are 
being rewritten every few months. 


	In December, Princeton University researchers detected the most  
distant quasar known. But the distance given, about 13 billion 
light-years away, was only a rough estimate and not as precise as 
the SUNY finding, which has been accepted by other astronomers as 
the most distant so far. Last May, a University of Hawaii team 
using the Keck telescope discovered a galaxy 12.3 billion 
light-years away. 


	The SUNY team examined a deep and narrow wedge of space in 1997,  
using a spectrograph and other instruments on the Hubble. They used 
computers to separate out 400 overlapping objects and uncover the 
distant galaxy. 


	The SUNY astronomers whimsically nicknamed their find after the  
sister of researcher Sebastian Pascarelle. 


	Sharon Pascarelle is a 32-year-old New York investment baker and  
``total liberal arts major'' who avoided science and math at 
Skidmore College. She became fascinated by her brother's dinnertime 
chat about the universe and pestered him to name something in the 
heavens after her. 


	She was flattered when he did so -- until she saw the galaxy's  
image and a blurted, ``It's just a dot!'' 


	``I wanted a planet named after me,'' she said. ``I guess I'll  
have to settle for a galaxy.'' 


	Sharon's fame may be fleeting -- both for the gal

results.content:
1999-06-02 00:40:07 
 usa 
 NASA Measure of Universe Questioned 


	CHICAGO (AP) -- A new radio-telescope technique has established a  
``golden ruler'' for measuring cosmic distances and raises doubts 
about the claim last week that NASA astronomers had determined the 
age and expansion rate of the universe. 


	Jim Herrnstein of the National Radio Astronomy Observatory said  
his method produces ``the most precise distance ever measured to a 
remote galaxy'' and suggests a 15 percent to 20 percent margin of 
error in the technique used by the astronomers sponsored by the 
National Aeronautics and Space Administration. 


	``Ours is a direct measurement, using geometry, and is  
independent of all other methods of determining cosmic distances,'' 
Herrnstein said Tuesday at a national meeting of the American 
Astronomical Society. 


	The NASA team led by Wendy Freedman of the Carnegie Institute in  
Washington said last week that they used the Hubble Space Telescope 
to successfully achieve the goal of measuring within an uncertainty 
of only 10 percent the speed at which the universe is expanding, a 
value called the Hubble constant. 


	Based on its study, the team concluded that the universe is 12  
billion to 13 billion years old and is expanding at an accelerating 
rate of 70 kilometers per second for every 3.3 million light-years 
in distance from the Earth. 


	Herrnstein said this calculation was off by as much as 20  
percent. He based his conclusion on the difference in calculated 
distance to a specific galaxy when comparing his technique with the 
method used by the NASA group. 


	Freedman and her team of 27 astronomers spent eight years  
measuring the distance to stars that pulsate in brightness at a 
known rate. Such stars, called cepheids, are considered ``standard 
candles'' whose varying luminosity gives a gauge for their 
distance. 


	But Herrnstein said the technique using cepheids is far less  
accurate than his new method that directly measures the motion of 
gas around a galaxy. 


	Herrnstein used a galaxy called NGC 4258 to establish what he  
called a ``golden ruler'' for measuring cosmic distances. 


	NGC 4258 is surrounded by a rotating cloud of gas. Within this  
gas cloud is water vapor, which tends to amplify radio signals. 
This creates radio ``hot spots'' called masers. 


	The orbital speed of masers between NGC 4258 and Earth was  
measured in 1994, and again every few months over the following 
three years. By determining the speed at which the masers were 
moving, the astronomers created a triangle with the first maser 
position at one angle, the latest position at a second angle and 
the galaxy center at the third angle. Measuring the angles gives 
the distance. 


	``We can use plain old trigonometry to calculate the distance,''  
said Lincoln Greenhill, a member of the Herrnstein team. 


	``It is very simple and direct,'' said Herrnstein. ``Most of us  
know enough math from high school to do the calculation.'' 


	The distance to NGC 4258 was calculated at 23.5 million  
light-years, with an accuracy to within 4 percent. This distance 
has been calculated using the cepheid star technique at 27 million 
to 29 million light-years. 


	Herrnstein said the distance measure using cepheid stars is  
based on a series of assumed values, such as the distance to the 
Large Magellanic Cloud, a galaxy neighbor to the Milky Way. These 
assumed values, said Herrnstein, have a greater margin of error 
than does the direct measuring technique he is using. 


	Freedman, who attended a news conference at which Herrnstein  
announced his results, said the new study provided ``wonderful 
data,'' but she would like other measurements to be taken to 
confirm its accuracy. 


	Also, she said the assumed values used in the cepheid star  
technique have been verified by a number of researchers and she was 
``confident'' of the results. Freedman admitted, however, that 
uncertainties in her team's results still needed to be checked out. 


	Herrnstein conducted his study using the Very Long Basel

results.content:
1999-08-26 12:50:20 
 washington 
 NASA Says New Telescope Works Well 


	WASHINGTON (AP) -- Crystal clear images of an exploding star  
confirmed that NASA's new $1 billion X-ray telescope is performing 
as expected, space agency officials and scientists said Thursday. 


	The orbiting telescope, called the Chandra X-ray Observatory,  
captured as its first view an image of the Cassiopeia A supernova, 
a star in the Milky Way galaxy that exploded about 300 years ago. 


	The image contains such detail of the explosion and its  
surrounding cloud that scientists say they have detected evidence 
of what may be a black hole near its center, a National Aeronautics 
and Space Administration announcement said. 


	A second image released Thursday shows an X-ray jet streaming  
some 200,000 light years into intergalactic space from a quasar 
some 6 billion light years away. 


	Quasars are distant, very energetic stellar objects that may  
spew forth X-rays and visible light equal to the total brightness 
of trillions of stars. A light year is the distance light travels 
across space in a year, about 6 trillion miles. 


	Chandra, the world's largest and most sensitive X-ray telescope,  
was launched July 23, and is still undergoing orbital checkout and 
calibration tests. But officials said the initial images show that 
the space telescope ``is in excellent health,'' a NASA statement 
said. 


	``We were astounded by these images,'' Harvey Tananbaum,  
director of the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory's Chandra 
X-ray Center in Cambridge, Mass., said in a statement. He said the 
images show in detail the shock wave racing away from the supernova 
center at millions of miles an hour. 


	``This observatory is ready to take its place in the history of  
spectacular scientific achievements,'' Martin Weisskopf, the 
Chandra Project Scientist, said in a statement. 


	Robert Kirshner, a Harvard University astronomer, said in a NASA  
statement that Chandra's ability to make high quality X-ray images 
of the universe ``will have an impact on virtually every area of 
astronomy.'' 


	Chandra joins NASA's fleet of orbiting observatories that  
include the Hubble Space Telescope, which collects images in 
visible light, and the Compton Gamma Ray Observatory, which studies 
gamma ray emissions in the universe. 


	Chandra operates from a high orbit, ranging from 6,000 to 86,400  
miles above the Earth. It detects X-rays, an invisible radiation 
that spews out from stars and fields of hot gas, such as those that 
might surround a black hole. Heated heavy elements in space give 
off X-rays of specific intensities. Chandra will be able to measure 
those intensities and identify specific elements, shedding new 
light on fundamental processes in the universe, officials said. 


	Chandra was named in honor of Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar, a  
pioneer astronomer at the University of Chicago and a winner of the 
Nobel Prize.

results.content:
ASTRONOMERS CATCH SIGHT OF GALAXIES ABORNING 



   In the beginning, there was light, the bursting dawn of cosmic
creation. As the fireball of the Big Bang expanded and cooled,
though, the light faded away and darkness fell on the young
universe, by then little more than a formless sea of dark matter
flecked with traces of primordial hydrogen and helium and broken
only by scattered but fateful ripples.


   The universe had entered what astronomers characterize as its
dark age. Over a period from 300,000 years to about half a billion
years after the Big Bang the darkness persisted, denying to
astronomers any direct evidence of this time of momentous
transformation. Somehow this epoch gave birth to the architecture
of the modern universe and conditions that would eventually lead to
planets and life.


   But what happened in the dark age and how the light came on
again is an enduring and frustrating mystery. If there was no light
or other detectable radiation from the dark age, what was there to
see? Besides, no telescope could see back that far. Sir Martin
Rees, a cosmologist at Cambridge University in England, calls this
the ``most important unsolved problem in astronomy.''


   In spite of the obstacles, by looking deeper and deeper into
space and thus into time with new telescopes in Earth orbit and on
the ground, astronomers are making progress in their search for the
first light.


   They are at last catching sight of some of the earlier, if not
necessarily the first, galaxies _ each observation seems to put
their formation back earlier in time. Astronomers are also
gathering clues to what makes up most of the universe, the
mysterious dark matter, and how it and other dark-age conditions
gave birth to the first stars and the first galaxies. The new
knowledge is enabling scientists to test their theories and conduct
increasingly detailed computer simulations of cosmic history,
including the dark age.


   The dark age ended when light returned to the firmament with the
emergence of the first stars and then vast communities of stars
gravitationally bound in galaxies. ``Suddenly, the universe lit up
like a Christmas tree,'' said Dr. Abraham Loeb, a theoretical
astrophysicist at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
in Cambridge, Mass.


   ``Somewhere in the dark age, the transition from the universe's
initial simple state to its current complex state occurred,'' Loeb
said. ``It would be philosophically exciting to glimpse that
moment.''


   A few years ago, Loeb recalled, he was one of a handful of
scientists studying the dark age and early star formation. But a
workshop on the subject at the University of Maryland last week
drew several dozen of the top observational and theoretical
astronomers. ``Now this has become a very hot topic,'' he said.


   Two weeks ago, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration
released pictures taken by the Hubble Space Telescope of what
astronomers think are the most distant galaxies ever studied. These
galaxies probably formed in the first billion years of cosmic
history, or more than 12 billion years ago. Such estimates are
rough because they depend on cosmological models and chronological
yardsticks based on the universe's being about 13 billion years
old, which is controversial and subject to revision.


   ``We have really made a step into new territory,'' said Dr.
Rodger I. Thompson, a University of Arizona astronomer who directed
the observations with the Earth-orbiting Hubble telescope's
near-infrared camera and spectrometer.


   Only an infrared camera can detect the faintest, most distant
galaxies. Dust in deep space obscures most visible light, more so
than radiation in the longer infrared wavelengths. And it is a
phenomenon of the expanding universe that the light emitted by a
galaxy gets stretched out to the redder and even near-infrared
wavelengths. At distances of vanishing visibility, the infrared
galactic light becomes the cosmic version of the Cheshire cat's
grin.


   The more distant galaxies have a higher expansion velocity and
thus a higher
