results.content:
1999-02-10 01:13:34 
 washington 
  Hubble May Have Early Planet Images 


	WASHINGTON (AP) -- Scientists may be getting a glimpse of the  
infancy of planets in new pictures from the Hubble Space Telescope. 


	Though the pictures released by NASA on Tuesday don't actually  
show planets, they give a look at disks of dust that circle young 
stars. Scientists believe that as stars age, this dust condenses to 
form planets. 


	Thus, the Hubble images may be offering a glimpse of what our  
solar system looked like 4.5 billion years ago when the Earth and 
other planets began to condense, the National Aeronautics and Space 
Administration reported. 


	NASA said Hubble was able to photograph the disks edge-on,  
avoiding the glare from the young suns that can overpower the light 
reflected from the dust. 


	``While the existence of these disks has been known from prior  
infrared and radio observations, the Hubble images reveal important 
new details such as a disk's size, shape, thickness and 
orientation,'' said Deborah Padgett of the California Institute of 
Technology's Infrared Processing and Analysis Center in Pasadena, 
Calif. 


	Her group used Hubble cameras to look at six young stars 450  
light-years away in the constellation Taurus. Light-years, used for 
measurement in space, represent the distance light travels in a 
year, or nearly 6 trillion miles. 


	In all six cases, the researchers found evidence of dust bands  
crossing bright areas around the star. 


	The images ``show dark clumps and bright streamers above and  
below the dust lanes, suggesting that raw material is still falling 
into these disks and driving outflowing jets of gas from the 
forming stars,'' Padgett said in a statement.

results.content:
1999-10-06 23:20:12 
 washington 
 Telescope Reveals Galaxy Bulges 


	WASHINGTON (AP) -- After taking a closer look at the centers of  
the massive spiral galaxies in space, scientists have found 
differences in how and when the star groups formed. 


	A pair of studies were released Wednesday by the National  
Aeronautics and Space Administration detailing what researchers 
have been able to learn using the Hubble space telescope. 


	The bulges of millions of stars in the more tightly wound spiral  
galaxies formed early in the life of the universe, according to a 
team led by Reynier Peletier of the University of Nottingham in 
England. 


	While a second team, led by C. Marcella Carollo of Columbia  
University in New York, concluded that galaxies with small bulges 
and long bars or lines of stars that bisect the nucleus grew more 
recently and through different processes. 


	The researchers say the central bulge stabilizes a galaxy's  
development and largely controls the ebb and flow of star birth in 
the core. 


	The Hubble telescope allows astronomers, who had previously been  
able to study only the bulge at the center of our own galaxy, to 
peer deep inside the bulges of other galaxies. 


	Carollo's team said the central bulge in the galaxies they  
studied probably formed early in the history of the universe, but 
was later fed by gas flowing into the galaxy's core, caused by 
instability in the surrounding disk of stars. 


	The gas fueled the birth of new stars, and the bulge grew, with  
bright star clusters populating the center. They found both young 
and old stars in the bulge. 


	Peletier's researchers studied the center of 20 spiral galaxies  
that have large bulges. They concluded that elliptical bulges of 
stars formed over a relatively brief period very early in the young 
universe, either through the collapse of a single cloud of hydrogen 
or the merger of primeval star clusters. 


	``The bulges of early spiral galaxies are old, and at least the  
outer parts of their disks are considerably younger,'' Peletier 
said in a statement. 


	The groups used Hubble telescope to study more than 200  
neighboring galaxies, out to a distance of 100 million light years. 
A light year is the distance light travels in a year. 


	Using visible light and infrared cameras, they were able to  
determine the stars' true colors. Older stars tend to be redder, 
but space dust can interfere with color perception from Earth. The 
Hubble space telescope permitted the researchers to look past that 
dust. 


	Peletier's report is scheduled for publication in Monthly  
Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society and Carollo's work will 
appear in Astrophysical Journal.

results.content:
1999-12-28 
 Space Shuttle Discovery Returns to Earth 


WASHINGTON, December 27 (Xinhua) -- U.S. space shuttle
Discovery returned to earth safely at 7:01 p.m. local time Monday
(0001 GMT Tuesday) at Kennedy Space Center after successfully
completing an eight-day mission.


The return ended the three-flight 1999 agenda of the National
Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA).


The space travel, originally scheduled for mid-October, finally
started on December 19 after nine delays. Although NASA officials
said the space shuttle was immune from the Millennium Bug, the
planned 10-day flight was cut to eight days to ensure its return
before the arrival of 2000 to avoid possible Y2K problems.


The major task of the eight-day flight was rescuing the failing
Hubble telescope through three spacewalks. The telescope had
stopped working since mid-November after four of its navigational
gyroscopes went wrong.


The astronauts replaced six gyroscopes in Hubble with new ones
in the first spacewalk. A more powerful CPU chip was installed in
it in the second walk.


Spacewalk three had a radio transmitter, a digital recorder and
anti-rays sun shades put in the three-billion-dollar telescope.


The refurbished telescope was then released back into the orbit
on December 25.


Scientists will test the telescope within the next two weeks
and it is expected to resume space explorations on January 9, said
NASA.


Hubble has served in space for nearly 10 years since it was
first launched in 1990, sending more than 259,000 valuable
pictures back to earth.

1999-05-25 23:21:52 
 washington 
 NASA: Universe 12 Billion Years Old 


	WASHINGTON (AP) -- A team of NASA astronomers says its  
measurements to pulsating stars suggest that the universe is about 
12 billion years old, somewhat younger than earlier estimates. 


	But other experts quickly said the NASA results are wrong and  
that, despite the agency's announcement Tuesday, the solution to a 
basic question in astronomy is still unknown. 


	A team of 27 astronomers funded by NASA and led by Wendy  
Freedman of the Carnegie Institute of Washington announced 
completion of an eight-year effort to measure the distance to 800 
special stars in order to calculate the speed at which all of the 
galaxies in the universe are moving apart. 


	Calculating that separation speed, called the Hubble constant,  
was a top priority of NASA's space telescope because the result is 
a critical factor in determining the age of the universe, Freedman 
said at a news conference. 


	Freedman said the Hubble constant was determined to an accuracy  
of 10 percent, and when this value is combined with other 
measurements, it gives an estimated age of the universe of about 12 
billion years. 


	This number could rise slightly, to perhaps 13.5 billion years,  
she said, if assumptions about the amount of matter in the universe 
change with further study. 


	NASA's announcement was quickly denounced by Allan Sandage, a  
legendary astronomer and head of a Carnegie Observatories team in 
Pasadena, Calif., that has searched for the Hubble constant since 
1968. 


	``If NASA is giving the impression that the problem is solved,  
then we would dispute that,'' Sandage said in a telephone 
interview. ``They have announced a final number, and they are not 
correct.'' 


	Astronomers have been searching for the Hubble constant since  
1929, when astronomer Edwin Hubble first found that distant 
galaxies are moving away from the Earth faster than are nearby 
galaxies. Astronomers express the Hubble constant by measuring the 
acceleration rate for every 3.26 million light years in distance. 


	Calculations using ground telescopes have ranged up to 558, but  
Freedman said new measurements taken with the space telescope have 
refined the acceleration rate to 70 kilometers per second. This 
means that a galaxy is moving 160,000 miles per hour faster for 
every 3.3 light years it is away from the Earth. Freedman said her 
figure was accurate within 10 percent. 


	Sandage said NASA's new number is still too high.  


	``We've said all along that the correct number is about 55,'' he  
said. This would give an age of the universe of 14 to 18 billion 
years, depending on what is assumed about the mass in the universe, 
Sandage said. 


	The expanding universe supports the Big Bang theory, the idea  
that the universe began when all matter was compressed into a 
single point that then exploded. The theory states that the 
universe has been expanding ever since. 


	Recent studies have shown that the universe probably will expand  
forever. Some researchers also believe the expansion is speeding up 
due to a force that accelerates matter. Whether this force exists 
is still a matter of controversy. 


	Freedman said the age of the universe will finally be determined  
when other researchers have more precisely measured the mass and 
the effect of the mysterious force. 


	The NASA team reached its Hubble constant number by measuring  
the distance to a type of star, called a Cepheid, that pulsates at 
a known rate and strength. By measuring Cepheids in 18 galaxies out 
to 65 million light years, Freedman said, the team established the 
rate of expansion. 


	Sandage said his team measured distances to nine star  
explosions, called supernovae, and then confirmed those distances 
with Cepheid measurements. He said this method is more accurate. 


	Both teams used the Hubble Space Telescope, which can study  
stellar detail that is unseen by ground telescopes. 


	Despite the difference in numbers, Robert Kirshner of Harvard,  
head of a third team studyin

results.content:
Astronomers detect faintest, most distant object ever


	   WASHINGTON (AP) _ The faintest and most distant objects ever
sighted _ galaxies of stars more than 12 billion light years away _
have been detected by an infrared camera on the Hubble Space
Telescope.
	   The sighting penetrates for the first time to within about one
billion light years of the very beginning of the universe,
astronomers said, and shows that even at that very early time there
already were galaxies with huge families of stars.
	   ``This is new territory,'' said Lisa Storrie-Lombardi, an
astronomer the Carnegie Observatories in Pasadena. ``We didn't
really know what we would see.''
	   ``We are seeing farther than ever before,'' said Rodger I.
Thompson, a University of Arizona astronomer and the principle
researcher in the study. ``We have not reached the edge (of the
universe), but we have made a step into a new area.''
	   Thompson and his team focused an infrared instrument on the
Hubble on a narrow patch of the sky that had been previously
photographed in visible light. The instrument detected about 100
galaxies that were not seen in the visible light and 10 of these
were at extreme distance.
	   He said the galaxies are seen as they were when the universe was
only about five percent of its present age. Astronomers generally
believe the universe began with a massive explosion, called the
``big bang'', that occurred about 13 billion years ago.
	   Since the big bang, astronomers believe that galaxies are moving
rapidly away from each other, spreading out and becoming more
distant. For this reason, distance and time can be measured
together. Light from the distant objects traveled for about 12
billion years before being detected by Hubble.
	   Infrared radiation cannot be seen by the eye, but it is the most
common type of light from distant galaxies. For this reason, said
Thompson, the infrared instrument could detect galaxies that were
invisible to earlier Hubble studies.
	   Thompson said that a more advanced space telescope, now in the
planning stages by NASA, will be needed to absolutely confirm the
distance and age of these faint objects.
	   ``We can see the objects clearly, but we can't get their age for
sure,'' said Thompson.
	   ``This is an exciting first step into this distant universe,''
said Alan Dressler, a Carnegie astronomer who was not a member of
the observing team. ``We're looking for zero (a time before stars
and galaxies had formed) and we haven't found it yet.''

results.content:
1999-10-06 13:00:20 
 washington 
 Telescope Reveals Galaxy Bulges 


	WASHINGTON (AP) -- The millions of stars bulging out amid the  
massive spiral galaxies whirling through space are beginning to 
reveal some details of how these star groups formed, NASA reported 
Wednesday. 


	The central bulges of the more tightly wound spiral galaxies  
formed early in the life of the universe, according to a team led 
by Reynier Peletier of the University of Nottingham in England. 


	A second team, led by C. Marcella Carollo of Columbia University  
in New York, concluded that galaxies with small bulges and long 
bars or lines of stars that bisect the nucleus grew more recently 
and through different processes. 


	The researchers say the central bulge stabilizes a galaxy's  
development and largely controls the ebb and flow of star birth in 
the core. 


	The Hubble telescope allows astronomers, who had previously been  
able to study only the bulge at the center of our own galaxy, to 
peer deep inside the bulges of other galaxies. 


	Carollo's team said the central bulge in the galaxies they  
studied probably formed early in the history of the universe, but 
was later fed by gas flowing into the galaxy's core, caused by 
instability in the surrounding disk of stars. 


	The gas fueled the birth of new stars, and the bulge grew, with  
bright star clusters populating the center. They found both young 
and old stars in the bulge. 


	Peletier's researchers studied the center of 20 spiral galaxies  
that have large bulges. They concluded that elliptical bulges of 
stars formed over a relatively brief period very early in the young 
universe, either through the collapse of a single cloud of hydrogen 
or the merger of primeval star clusters. 


	``The bulges of early spiral galaxies are old, and at least the  
outer parts of their disks are considerably younger,'' Peletier 
said in a statement. 


	The groups used Hubble telescope to study more than 200  
neighboring galaxies, out to a distance of 100 million light years. 
A light year is the distance light travels in a year. 


	Using visible light and infrared cameras, they were able to  
determine the stars' true colors. Older stars tend to be redder, 
but space dust can interfere with color perception from Earth. The 
Hubble space telescope permitted the researchers to look past that 
dust. 


	Peletier's report is scheduled for publication in Monthly  
Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society and Carollo's work will 
appear in Astrophysical Journal.

results.content:
HUBBLE PHOTOS SHED NEW LIGHT ON BIRTH OF PLANETS 



   Photographs from the Hubble Space Telescope are providing a
picture of how the Earth's solar system formed, helping to confirm
astronomers' theories of how planets are born, astronomers report.


   None of the pictures actually show planets, which are too faint
to be seen at even the distances of the nearest stars. But they do
show swirling disks of gas and dust around newborn stars, in some
cases with gaps or holes in the disks that seem to show the effects
of planets. Astronomers believe that all planets, including Earth,
originally formed from such disks.


   The Hubble images, showing young stars at various stages in the
early formation of planets, can be assembled into a sequence that
shows how the process unfolds, the astronomers said this week at a
National Aeronautics and Space Administration briefing.


   Though the stars differ somewhat in size from our sun, these
images of the various embryonic stages of planet formation may be
the closest thing we will ever have to baby pictures of our solar
system in its formative years, the astronomers said.


   ``We now have an assembly of pictures that span almost the
entire evolutionary sequence'' of the sun and its planets, said
Steven Beckwith, director of the Space Telescope Science Institute
in Baltimore.


   Most of the new pictures were taken of one of the nearest
interstellar clouds where stars are being born, in the
constellation of Taurus. These stars, imaged by astronomer Deborah
Padgett and her colleagues using a camera on the Hubble telescope
that picks up infrared light, are about 450 light years (or about
2.7 quadrillion miles) from Earth. Most of the images show dark
bands cutting through the bright image of a star, because the dusty
disks are seen edge-on from Earth's perspective.


   The pictures provide strong support for theories of planet
formation which were formulated decades ago, long before
astronomers thought that it would be possible to see such processes
in action anytime in the foreseeable future. ``It's a good example
of a theory that's been around for a long time, but we were only
able to check it in recent years,'' Beckwith said.


   Surveys of nearby regions of space where stars are forming from
large gas clouds seem to show that the vast majority of stars _ and
perhaps virtually all of them _ are surrounded by such
``protoplanetary disks'' early in their lifetimes. This is good
news for those who hope to find signs of intelligent beings out
among the stars, because it suggests that most stars will
ultimately be found to have planets _ presumed to be the likeliest
place to find life.


   Still, since none of the actual planets in such systems can yet
be seen, the astronomers cautioned that it is too soon to be sure
what the pictures mean. David Leckrone, senior NASA scientist for
the Hubble project, said that ``it's a good halftime score, but the
game isn't over yet.''


   And Beckwith added ``until we can actually see the planets, we
won't know for sure.'' Still, he said, the images are good news for
the theorists because they fit the expected picture. The proof may
require direct detection of planets, he said. But in the meantime,
while it may be possible to come up with alternative explanations
for some individual pictures, other than current ideas about the
birth of planetary systems ``there isn't any other theory that
could account for this whole range of observations.''

results.content:
&QL;  WORLD'S MOST EXPENSIVE JUNK COMES HOME


   By Jonathan Lipman


   Special to space.com


   WASHINGTON (States News Service) - What do you do with a junky
old computer? Throw it out? Donate it to a school? Cannibalize it
for parts? Or, you could do as NASA does, and store it in an inert
nitrogen envelope in a corner of the world's largest clean room.


   The Hubble Space Telescope's DF-224 will be the world's most
expensive obsolete computer when astronauts bring it back from the
telescope later this month. Although the old computer, Hubble's
original, isn't necessarily all that expensive in-and-of itself,
its launch to orbit and return cost roughly $1.8 million. (NOTE TO
EDITORS: NASA VERY ROUGH ESTIMATE OF LAUNCH COSTS &QC; $9,000/LB. WEIGHT
OF OLD COMPUTER &QC; 100 LBS. 9,000 $/LB x 100 LB x 2 FLIGHTS  &QC; 
$1,800,000)


   As a result, NASA is reluctant to simply throw the thing away.


   ``Engineers by nature are kind of pack rats,'' said Preston
Burch, the project manager for HST Operations. ``If you ever came
to my office, it would scare you.''


   Burch has racks of 'junk' stored at his facility, which he takes
out now and then to fiddle with for testing and diagnostic reasons.


   Normally, anything that comes back from Hubble is examined
closely and often recycled for reuse. This is the third servicing
mission to the telescope, and astronauts have brought back old
components on each earlier flight. These obsolete and often broken
pieces of equipment are some of the only objects ever returned to
Earth from an extended stay in orbit.


   ``Outer space is one of the greatest long-term storage
environments there is,'' Burch said. ``There's not any dirt to get
on it, there's no one to get one of their greasy hands on it.''


   NASA recycles what it can. For instance, a previous crew
installed the Wide Field Planetary Camera 2, the workhorse
instrument that takes most pictures from Hubble, and ferried the
first model back to Earth. The first camera has been stripped and
remodeled, and will go back to orbit next year as 'WFPC3.'


   ``If it's an instrument and it's coming back and it's in
perfectly good shape, we'll send it to another contractor,'' Burch
said. ``We'll definitely want to use the flight structure and the
latches, and maybe the optical bench - that's a structure that's
designed to be very rigid that holds all of the optical
components...it has to be very precise.''


   But Hubble is ten years old, and has been very busy. Some parts
have ``degraded'' as NASA says, like the stabilizing gyroscopes the
current Discovery crew is replacing. Wires inside the gyroscope
have corroded because of exposure to oxygen and are now, well,
junk.


   Burch wants them back anyway.


   ``Usually we're replacing the originals because they failed,''
Burch said. ``And one of the things we want to know is why it
failed.''


   Before they get components back from orbit, NASA's engineers are
often pressed to find out what went wrong with a part by reading
all the telemetry from the satellite, so that they can re-design
the part. When the part comes back, the staff at NASA Goddard
center likes to test their earlier hypotheses.


   When they're done inspecting, dissecting, and rejecting the
part, it goes into storage. NASA staff like to keep it around to
help them diagnose problems with new parts, Burch said. If one of
the new gyroscopes starts showing a problem, for instance,
engineers will haul out the old ones to see if they can make it
behave the same way in a lab.


   Goddard has the largest clean room of its kind in the world,
needed to build the Hubble, and has plenty of space. Failing that,
Burch said, engineers can seal the part in a plastic container with
dry nitrogen - all water vapor removed - to prevent corrosion.


   ``The very last thing we'd ever do is throw it in the
dumpster,'' Burch said.


   The old computer, however, is ``a different animal,'' he said.
It's not dumpster-bound, but it's not something Burch even really
needs to look at. Because of the radiation in space, satellite
c

results.content:
Astronomers sweep away cosmic dust; reveal more and younger


	   DENVER (AP) _ Astronomers using a sensitive new instrument have
lifted a dusty veil shrouding the universe to reveal galaxies
forming at a furious pace much deeper in space and far earlier in
time than expected.
	   A pair of studies to be published Thursday in the journal Nature
describe developing ``starburst'' galaxies observed for the first
time in patches of space at least 11 billion light-years from
Earth.
	   The galaxies were detected indirectly, by energy emissions. They
cannot be seen by optical telescopes because they are camouflaged
by dust that is characteristic of galaxies in their early stages of
development.
	   Researchers say the discoveries by astronomers at the University
of Edinburgh Royal Observatory in Scotland and the University of
Hawaii show that sections of the deep sky that had appeared empty
actually might be crammed with thousands of these bright objects,
each of which might contain billions of hot, young stars. In fact,
these starburst galaxies may be as common as all of the space
objects spotted by optical telescopes.
	   The discoveries demonstrate that astronomers may have been
missing a vital, formative period in the history of the universe.
	   The deeper astronomers peer into space, the farther back in time
they are looking. It takes so long for light from a star to reach
Earth that astronomers peering toward the far edges of space are
seeing objects as they were billions of years ago.
	   With potentially so many young starburst galaxies out there,
astronomers may have been drastically underestimating when galaxies
started forming and the rate at which they formed.
	   Up to now, astronomers believed a peak period of galaxy
formation occurred when the universe was 8 billion to 10 billion
years old. (The universe is thought to be 13 billion to 15 billion
years old.)
	   But this newly observed burst of galaxy formation may have
occurred much earlier _ perhaps when the universe was less than 2
billion years old.
	   ``The question as to exactly how far back in time this has taken
place still has some uncertainty associated with it,'' said Robert
Williams, director of the Space Telescope Science Institute in
Baltimore. ``However, the basic interpretation should be correct.''
	   Also, this stellar baby boom may have peaked at a rate five to
100 times greater than previously estimated, the researchers said.
	   The findings may prompt astronomers to rewrite some early
chapters in the story of the universe.
	   ``Early, rapid star formation implies that the very first
objects might have had to form much earlier still,'' said Douglas
Scott, an astronomer at the University of British Columbia.
	   The studies were conducted in 1997-98 with the Submillimeter
Common-User Bolometer Array, or SCUBA. The instrument, developed by
the University of Edinburgh, is mounted on a 15-meter telescope at
the Mauna Kea observatory in Hawaii.
	   SCUBA has detectors that make the most rapid and extensive
measurements of invisible far-infrared light from deep space. The
very dust that obscures the young galaxies absorbs heat from the
new stars and re-radiates it in faint, longer wavelengths that
SCUBA picks up.
	   The Royal Observatory scanned a portion of the sky known as the
Hubble Deep Field.
	   Astronomers used the Hubble Space Telescope in 1995 to zero in
on that region, which was thought to be a dull cosmic neighborhood.
As it turned out, the Hubble, using a regular optical telescope and
other instruments, found more than 3,000 galaxies, each containing
10 billion stars.
	   The Royal Observatory astronomers used SCUBA to look even deeper
into that portion of the sky and detected even more galaxies.
	   The other study, conducted by astronomer Amy Barger of the
University of Hawaii and seven collaborators, including four from
Japan, used SCUBA to look at other patches of the sky.

results.content:
HUBBLE DISCOVERS PLANETS CIRCLING A STAR 



   AUSTIN, Texas _ Spectacular new pictures taken by the Hubble
Space Telescope reveal strong evidence of two planets circling a
nearby star, which would make it the first multiple-planet system
discovered beyond our own.


   The narrow dust ring that photographs show around a star in the
constellation Libra is, astronomers believe, kept in place by two
``shepherding'' planets.


   So far, 17 other stars have been found to have planets, but only
one planet has been detected in each case. Astronomers have long
hoped to find a multiple-planet system other than our own, because
studying such systems could help to reveal more about the process
of how planets form, and show that our sun's family is not unique.


   The only multiple planets found before were orbiting the
burned-out remnants of dead stars, called pulsars, and are thought
to have been formed by completely different processes than normal
planets. Furthermore, they are in hellish environments of high
temperature and radiation that preclude any possibility of life _
one of the main reasons astronomers are interested in finding other
planets in the first place.


   The ring gives the star in Libra an appearance very much like
that of the ringed planet Saturn in our own solar system, and
astronomer Bradley Smith of the University of Hawaii said at a
meeting of the American Astronomical Society that the ring around
the star HR4796A almost certainly formed in the same way as one of
Saturn's narrow outer rings.


   Those rings are held in place by two moons orbiting very close
to them, one just inside the ring and one just outside. Without
these ``shepherding'' moons, the rings would quickly spread out
into a broad disk.


   In the same way, Smith said Friday, there is no known way a
narrow ring of small particles around another star could exist
without the presence of a pair of sheperding planets _ even though
the planets themselves cannot yet be seen in these Hubble images.


   Geoffrey Marcy, the University of California at San Francisco
astronomer who has discovered or co-discovered most of the planets
beyond the sun that have been found so far, agreed Friday that
``when you see rings, something has to confine those rings.'' That
something, according to the Hubble team, must be planets, because
anything larger would certainly have been visible in the pictures.


   Several other stars have been found in recent years to be
surrounded by disks of dust and gas, but this is the first case of
a ring around another sun _ and thus the first clear evidence for
planets ever found in this way.


   Other planets of nearby stars have been discovered by analyzing
the motions of the stars themselves to see the telltale wobbles in
their motions caused by the gravitational pull of planets. And the
existence of one planet was inferred around a star called Beta
Pictoris because of a warping seen in a disk of gas that surrounds
that star.


   The new pictures were taken by a camera called NICMOS, or
Near-Infrared Camera and Multi-Object Spectrometer, installed on
the Hubble telescope during its last servicing mission by space
shuttle astronauts.


   Another picture taken by NICMOS as part of the same series of
images of stars in search of dust disks also provides evidence for
a planet. In this case, the planet is revealed by the presence of a
dark gap in an otherwise continuous disk of dust surrounding the
star, suggesting that a planet has swept clean a path through the
disk. This apparent planet was found by a team of astronomers at
the University of California at Los Angeles.


   And four other stars whose pictures were taken by NICMOS also
show signs of the influence of planets, but the astronomers have
not yet had time to study these closely and could not yet provide
any details.


   Smith said that astronomers had known that it might be possible
for such a narrow ring of debris to be found around another star,
but he said that ``we knew it could exist, but we didn't really
expect to see it.''

results.content:
NEWS STORY 
 2000-06-13 15:25 
 Round, Hologram Stamps Planned  


   WASHINGTON (AP) -- America's first round, five-sided and hologram
stamps will be issued next month, the Postal Service announced
Tuesday.


   The new issues will be released at World Stamp Expo 2000, being
held in Anaheim, Calif.


   A ''Space Achievement and Exploration'' stamp will be issued
July 7. The round stamp will bear a hologram of Earth, using images
supplied by NASA. It is both the first round stamp issued by the
United States, as well as the first hologram stamp, although there
have been stamped envelopes with holograms issued.


   The stamp will cover the $11.75 Express mail rate.


   On July 8 a second hologram stamp will be issued, also at the
$11.75 rate, featuring a hologram of a lunar lander, based on
computer images and a three-dimensional model from NASA.


   Two ''Escaping the Gravity of Earth'' hologram stamps will be
issued July 9. The Priority Mail rate --$3.20 -- stamps feature
holograms of the International Space Station.


   On July 10, six ''Probing the Vastness of Space'' stamps will be
issued. These 60-cent international rate stamps depict an
illustration of the Hubble Space Telescope and photographs of the
Very Large Array telescope system on the Plains of San Agustin,
near Socorro, N.M.; twin 10-meter optical and infrared telescopes
at Keck Observatory in Mauna Kea, Hawaii; optical telescopes at the
Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory near La Serena, Chile; the
100-inch optical telescope at Mount Wilson Observatory, near
Pasadena, Calif.; and a 305-meter radio telescope at Arecibo
Observatory in Puerto Rico.


   July 11 marks the first day for five ''Exploring the Solar
System'' stamps, the first five-sided stamps in U.S. postal
history.


   These $1 stamps present an image of a solar eclipse from a
satellite, an illustrated cutaway view of the sun, a digitally
restored NASA image of sunrise from space, an image of a solar
eruption taken by Skylab and a photo from Earth of the sun in a
partly cloudy sky.


   ------


   On the Net: U.S. Postal Service:
http://new.usps.com/cgi-bin/uspsbv/scripts/front.jsp

results.content:
SCIENTISTS CALL PHOTOS FROM SPACE OBSERVATORY `ASTOUNDING' 




   Astronomers displayed the first images taken by NASA's $1.55
billion Chandra X-ray Observatory on Thursday, declaring the new
telescope in perfect working order and the picture quality
``astounding.''


   ``It works. It works perfectly. It meets all of our
specifications,'' said Ed Weiler, NASA's associate administrator
for space science. ``We have the most powerful X-ray observatory in
the world.''


   The first pictures included:


   _ An immense sizzling interstellar cloud left by a star 10,000
light years away that exploded 320 years ago. Detected for the
first time amid the remnant gases of Cassiopeia A is a small bright
object that may be the dense neutron star produced in the
explosion.


   _ A quasar 6 billion light years away. Astronomers believe the
large black hole it harbors is responsible for the fierce,
high-velocity gas jet streaking from the object across a distance
twice as wide as the Milky Way galaxy.


   Nine years ago, Weiler had the unpleasant duty of disclosing
that the Hubble Space Telescope had been launched with a misshapen
mirror, corrected three years later by spacewalking astronauts.


   This time, there was nothing but praise for Chandra, a sister of
the Hubble. It was launched in July to study the high energy X-ray
emissions from stellar explosions, galactic collisions and black
holes.


   ``It's really astounding,'' said Harvey Tananbaum, director of
the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory's Chandra X-ray Center in
Cambridge, Mass., noting the images of Cassiopeia were taken in
less than 90 minutes. ``It's just a glimpse, a first look at the
kinds of things that Chandra will be able to see. We couldn't be
more delighted.''


   The 45-foot long telescope was launched July 22 aboard the
shuttle Columbia, whose five-member crew was led by Air Force Col.
Eileen Collins, the first woman spacecraft commander.


   It was deployed by the shuttle crew less than 200 miles above
the Earth, then a combination of propulsion devices lofted the big
telescope into a looping orbit.


   The trajectory takes the telescope as far as 86,500 miles from
the Earth, or about a third of the way to the moon.


   The unusual orbit places the telescope above the Earth's Van
Allen radiation belt, which would interfere with the observations.


   The protective door over the barrel of the telescope was opened
in response to remote commands Aug. 12 and the images displayed
Thursday were taken about a week ago.


   Astronomers have not had the opportunity to scrutinize them with
the same diligence they will apply to the observations that follow.


   When they aimed the telescope at the distant quasar as part of a
calibration exercise, they expected only to see a bright point of
light. The fine resolution came as a surprise.


   Chandra was designed for at least five years of observations.
However, it is in an orbit stable enough to afford a 30- to 50-year
lifetime, officials said.


   X-ray astronomy is a field born of the Space Age. The Earth's
atmosphere blocks the harmful form of radiance from reaching
ground-based observatories.


   Chandra is the third of NASA's series of great observatories.
The Compton Gamma Ray Observatory joined the Hubble in orbit in
1991. The last in the series, the Space Infrared Telescope
Facility, is planned for launching in 2001.


   &QL; 
XXXX END OF STORY &QL;

results.content:
ASTRONOMERS ESTABLISH MORE RELIABLE RATE FOR UNIVERSE'S EXPANSION 



   After eight years of measurements by the Hubble Space Telescope,
astronomers think they have finally established a reliable value to
the expansion rate of the universe, the indispensable number
required for determining the age, size and fate of the universe.


   It is a number that scientists have sought ever since 1929, when
Edwin P. Hubble discovered that the galaxies are flying outward at
velocities that increase with distance. Estimates of the expansion
rate, also known as the Hubble constant, are fundamental to all
theories of cosmic evolution. But they have fluctuated wildly
between numbers that would put the age of the universe anywhere
from 10 billion to 20 billion years.


   By the new calculations, announced Tuesday, the universe has
been expanding for at least 12 billion years since its theorized
explosive creation in the Big Bang. Depending on the density of
cosmic matter and the possible existence of a mysterious form of
vacuum energy, the age of the universe could be closer to 13.5
billion or even 15 billion years.


   Astronomers said they had 90 percent confidence in the
reliability of the basic measurement underlying these age
estimates. The number of the Hubble constant, they concluded, is
70, plus or minus 7. That means that a galaxy appears to be flying
away at a rate of 70 kilometers per second per megaparsec, or
160,000 miles per hour faster for every 3.26 light-years it is away
from Earth.


   A team of scientists led by Wendy L. Freedman of the Carnegie
Observatories in Pasadena, Calif., determined the expansion rate by
using the Earth-orbiting Hubble telescope in measuring distances to
800 stars of known brightness, called Cepheid stars, in 18
galaxies. Measuring the expansion rate was the telescope's top
scientific objective.


   ``After all these years, we are finally entering an era of
precision cosmology,'' Freedman said in announcing the findings at
NASA in Washington. ``Now we can more reliably address the broader
picture of the universe's origin, evolution and destiny.''


   Only a decade ago, astronomers argued over wide differences in
expansion-rate estimates, which resulted in a range of cosmic ages
running from 10 billion to 20 billion years. The first tentative
results by Freedman's group, reported five years ago, seemed to
defy logic. An expansion rate of 80 yielded age estimates ranging
from 8 billion to 12 billion years, which made the universe younger
than its oldest stars.


   Freedman said in an interview that the lower value for the
Hubble constant, as well as the team's confidence in the research,
stemmed from an increase in observational data through different
methods and a careful analysis of possible sources of uncertainty
or error.


   Now the estimates by rival teams are beginning to converge on
numbers that lead to ages of the universe similar to or greater
than the ages of the stars. But the controversy has not entirely
ended.


   ``We used to disagree by a factor of two; now we are just as
passionate about 10 percent,'' said Robert Kirshner of the
Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics in Cambridge, Mass. ``A
factor of two is like being unsure if you have one foot or two. Ten
percent is like arguing about one toe. It's a big step forward.''


   Freedman's adversary in the Hubble constant wars has been Allan
R. Sandage, also at the Carnegie Observatories. His observations of
distances to certain types of exploding stars have consistently led
to lower values for the Hubble constant, usually less than 60, and
thus greater ages for the universe, from 15 billion to 20 billion
years.

the value is between 53 and 65. The curves are going to intersect
in 2006.''

conflict.''

results.content:
ASTRONOMERS ESTABLISH MORE RELIABLE RATE FOR UNIVERSE'S EXPANSION 



   After eight years of measurements by the Hubble Space Telescope,
astronomers think they have finally established a reliable value to
the expansion rate of the universe, the indispensable number
required for determining the age, size and fate of the universe.


   It is a number that scientists have sought ever since 1929, when
Edwin P. Hubble discovered that the galaxies are flying outward at
velocities that increase with distance. Estimates of the expansion
rate, also known as the Hubble constant, are fundamental to all
theories of cosmic evolution. But they have fluctuated wildly
between numbers that would put the age of the universe anywhere
from 10 billion to 20 billion years.


   By the new calculations, announced Tuesday, the universe has
been expanding for at least 12 billion years since its theorized
explosive creation in the Big Bang. Depending on the density of
cosmic matter and the possible existence of a mysterious form of
vacuum energy, the age of the universe could be closer to 13.5
billion or even 15 billion years.


   Astronomers said they had 90 percent confidence in the
reliability of the basic measurement underlying these age
estimates. The number of the Hubble constant, they concluded, is
70, plus or minus 7. That means that a galaxy appears to be flying
away at a rate of 70 kilometers per second per megaparsec, or
160,000 miles per hour faster for every 3.26 million light-years
away from Earth.


   A team of scientists led by Wendy L. Freedman of the Carnegie
Observatories in Pasadena, Calif., determined the expansion rate by
using the Earth-orbiting Hubble telescope in measuring distances to
800 stars of known brightness, called Cepheid stars, in 18
galaxies. Measuring the expansion rate was the telescope's top
scientific objective.


   ``After all these years, we are finally entering an era of
precision cosmology,'' Freedman said in announcing the findings at
NASA in Washington. ``Now we can more reliably address the broader
picture of the universe's origin, evolution and destiny.''


   Only a decade ago, astronomers argued over wide differences in
expansion-rate estimates, which resulted in a range of cosmic ages
running from 10 billion to 20 billion years. The first tentative
results by Freedman's group, reported five years ago, seemed to
defy logic. An expansion rate of 80 yielded age estimates ranging
from 8 billion to 12 billion years, which made the universe younger
than its oldest stars.


   Freedman said in an interview that the lower value for the
Hubble constant, as well as the team's confidence in the research,
stemmed from an increase in observational data through different
methods and a careful analysis of possible sources of uncertainty
or error.


   Now the estimates by rival teams are beginning to converge on
numbers that lead to ages of the universe similar to or greater
than the ages of the stars. But the controversy has not entirely
ended.


   ``We used to disagree by a factor of two; now we are just as
passionate about 10 percent,'' said Robert Kirshner of the
Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics in Cambridge, Mass. ``A
factor of two is like being unsure if you have one foot or two. Ten
percent is like arguing about one toe. It's a big step forward.''


   Freedman's adversary in the Hubble constant wars has been Allan
R. Sandage, also at the Carnegie Observatories. His observations of
distances to certain types of exploding stars have consistently led
to lower values for the Hubble constant, usually less than 60, and
thus greater ages for the universe, from 15 billion to 20 billion
years.


   At a recent science conference in Baltimore, Sandage, referring
to his own results, reported: ``At a 99 percent confidence level,
the value is between 53 and 65. The curves are going to intersect
in 2006.''


   Kirshner remarked, ``We are no longer talking about a real
conflict.''


   As Freedman and others observed, the margins for error in the
two sets of Hubble constant estimates are such that

2000-05-22 
 Canadian Scientists Create Tiniest Telescope 


Unlike NASA's huge Hubble space observatory, Canada's
observatory has a telescope the size of a pie plate and will be
carried on a satellite the size of a suitcase.


Despite its small size, the telescope, officially called MOST,
will measure minuscule vibrations in distant stars that are
undetectable by Hubble and by the largest telescopes on Earth.


The 50-kg. telescope is also unique in the way it is designed
to stay rock-steady, said the newspaper.


The project of 7 million Canadian dollars (about 4.7 million U.
S. dollars) was designed by the University of British Columbia.

results.content:
1998-06-10 
 NASA to Launch Spacecraft Observatory in 2007 


WASHINGTON, June 9 (Xinhua) -- U.S. NASA will launch a next
generation space telescope -- Spacecraft Observatory -- in 2007 to
succeed the Hubble Space Telescope which will retire in 2010, The
Washington Post reported here Tuesday.


The Spacecraft Observatory will be operated by the Space
Telescope Science Institute at Johns Hopkins University.


Making the announcement, NASA's Administrator Dan Goldin said
that the next generation space telescope would be positioned
nearly a million miles from Earth -- three times farther away than
Hubble. It also will be three times larger and 10 times more
sensitive to light and will peer much farther into space.


"This telescope is going to be a revolution," Goldin said. "We
will go to the very edge of what we believe was the creation" of
the universe.

results.content:
1996-11-08 
 Chinese Astronomers To View Sun From Outer Space 


BEIJING, November 8 (Xinhua) -- Chinese Astronomers are
co-operating with their German colleagues in implementing plans
for the world's largest solar telescope, a 1.2-ton model that is
one meter in diameter.


"A research report will be signed by the two sides soon, and
subject to government approval, involving 600 million yuan in
total investment, half from each side, will be put into the
project to get it to the design stage," sai Ai Guoxiang, a member
of the Chinese Academy of Sciences and the head of the project.


He explained that part of the project has already been carried
out for design and production of the telescope.


The telescope will be put in space in 2001 or 2002. It has 0.1
arc second of angular resolution, the same as the Hubble Space
Telescope.


"The Hubble telescope is useful for night astronomy (weak
light) and the solar telescope for daytime use (strong light). It
is significant for research on the impact of solar eruptions on
outer space and on man's environment," he added.


It was only after two major technological breakthroughs, the
solar magnetic field telescope and the multichannel solar
telescope, that it was possible to build the large solar
telescope. The largest land-based symmetrical solar telescope now
being built is 90 cm in diameter.


"The advantage of space astronomy lies in great wavelength,
continuous coverage, omni-directional observation, and avoiding
disturbances produced by the earth's atmosphere," Professor Ai
noted.


Next year will be a crucial year for the solar telescope
project, when an 80-cm-dia. solar telescope will be sent up as
high as 32 km in a hot air balloon to do tests for the outer space
telescope.

results.content:
1999-07-18 13:10:11 
 usa 
 Powerful Telescope Set for Launch 


	CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (AP) -- The world's heftiest, mightiest,  
priciest X-ray telescope is about to embark on a five-year voyage 
to stare deep into the hearts of galaxies and search for signs of 
black holes. 


	The Chandra X-ray Observatory, a 4 1/2-story colossus stuffed into  
space shuttle Columbia and due to lift off Tuesday, is 10 to 100 
times more powerful than any of the dozen or so X-ray telescopes 
previously placed in orbit. 


	If words glimmered in X-rays, Chandra could read a newspaper  
from a half-mile away or make out the letters of a stop sign from 
12 miles away. 


	``We can make Superman jealous, I guess, with our X-ray  
vision,'' NASA manager Ken Ledbetter says with a smile. 


	The astronauts, led by NASA's first female space shuttle  
commander, Eileen Collins, will release Chandra with the flick of a 
switch seven hours after launch. It will be another month before 
the telescope's eagerly awaited observations begin. 


	X-rays are produced by quasars, galaxies, remnants of exploded  
stars and other celestial objects, but are invisible to 
ground-based telescopes. 


	They would go right through flat mirrors, like those used to  
focus light on the Hubble Space Telescope, or the lenses used in 
many smaller telescopes, so Chandra uses conical mirrors. The 
X-rays will glance off the sloping glass at a shallow angle like 
pebbles skipping across a pond. 


	``This is an age that we live in where superlatives are used in  
everything from sports to politics, probably a little bit too 
much,'' says Martin Weisskopf, a NASA scientist who has been 
working on the project for two decades. ``But I can't help but use 
those superlatives with this observatory. They are really well 
based.'' 


	The telescope, built by TRW Inc., cost $1.5 billion to develop.  
Throw in the shuttle ride and five years of orbital operations, and 
the price jumps to $2.8 billion, making it one of NASA's most 
expensive science projects ever. 


	Chandra -- named for the late astrophysicist who won a Nobel  
Prize -- is the third of NASA's four so-called Great Observatories. 
The first was Hubble and the second was the Compton Gamma Ray 
Observatory, launched in 1991. 


	With Chandra's help, astronomers hope to learn how much  
so-called dark matter is out there and where it is, and more about 
the matter swirling into black holes and the high-energy jets of 
matter shooting away from them. They also hope to better calculate 
the distance to celestial objects, useful in estimating the size 
and age of the universe. 


	Chandra should have flown last summer, but was sidelined by bad  
circuit boards and other problems. 


	Also causing heartburn for NASA in recent months has been the  
rocket motor that's attached to Chandra, because it is similar to 
one that malfunctioned on an Air Force satellite in April and left 
that spacecraft in a worthless orbit. 


	The solid-rocket motor is needed to propel Chandra from the  
relatively low altitude of the shuttle into a lopsided orbit with a 
low point of 6,200 miles and a high point of 87,000 miles -- 
one-third of the way to the moon. 


	Chandra, the rocket motor and support gear together weigh 50,000  
pounds, making it the heaviest shuttle payload ever. 


	NASA officials say they're confident the thoroughly checked  
motor -- and the telescope itself -- will work. 


	Hubble was launched in 1990 with a flawed mirror that blurred  
its vision. It took millions of dollars and a daring space shuttle 
mission to correct Hubble's eyesight, now the envy of the world. 


	Rigorous testing of Chandra's fully assembled optics uncovered  
no flaws, says NASA's top space scientist, Ed Weiler. 


	Still not satisfied, Weiler just a few months ago asked a favor  
of the director of the Chandra X-ray Observatory Center in 
Cambridge, Mass. 


	``Come up with the grossest, most outlandish problems that you  
can think of and then make a list and go look at them and make sure 
that they're not there,'' Weiler asked.

results.content:
1996-07-09 
 S. Africa Achieves Progress in Astronomy 


JOHANNESBURG, July 9 (Xinhua) -- Two South African astronomers
have for the first time measured the diameters of two variable
stars by using the Hubble space telescope (HST), the South
African Astronomical Observatory (SAAO) announced today in Cape
Town.


Patricia Whitelock of the SAAO and Michael Feast of the
University of Cape Town, part of an international team including
two Italians using HST, made the difficult and accurate
measurements from space.


The stars measured were well-known variables in the
constellations of Leo, the lion and Hdra, the Water Monster.


Whitelock said: "We pick these particular stars because we
think they are very much like the kind of star our own sun."


"By studying them, we'll know more about what will happen to
our sun, and us, in the far distant future," he added.


Meanwhile, Feast said the stars behave in a strange way. "They
actually pulsate, getting bigger and smaller."


Feast also said they are continuing to take measurements with
the HST to see how much sizes and shapes of the stars changed in
the course of the year.

results.content:
1998-10-10 
 Hubble Detects Most Distant Galaxies 


WASHINGTON, October 9 (Xinhua) -- U.S. Hubble Space Telescope
has detected galaxies of stars more than 12 billion light-years
away, The Washington Post reported Friday.


Rodger I. Thompson, an astronomer from the University of
Arizona, and his team focused an infrared instrument on the
Telescope on a narrow patch of space and detected about 100
galaxies never before seen, and 10 of them were at extreme
distance.


Thompson said that the galaxies are seen as they were when the
universe was only about 5 percent of its present age.


Astronomers generally think the universe began with the "big
bang" about 13 billion years ago. Since then, the galaxies have
been moving rapidly away from each other, spreading out and
becoming more distant. For this reason, distance and time can be
measured together. Light from the distant objects traveled for
about 12 billion years before being detected by Hubble.


A light-year equals about 6 trillion miles.

1999-05-19 10:56:03 
 washington 
  Astronomers Spot Storm on Mars 


	WASHINGTON (AP) -- A cyclone four times the size of Texas raged  
across the northern polar region of the planet Mars last month, 
according to space telescope views of the red planet. 


	The Space Telescope Science Institute announced today that the  
Hubble Space Telescope on April 27 spotted an immense Martian storm 
cloud, made up of water ice, that was 1,100 miles long and 900 
wide. 


	Bands of clouds spiraled in a counterclockwise motion around a  
200-mile wide eye in the center of the storm, taking on a shape 
that resembled hurricanes on Earth, astronomers said. 


	The storm occurred during the summer in Mars' northern  
hemisphere. It came after seasonal warming evaporated the carbon 
dioxide ice sheet that caps the Martian north pole during part of 
the year. 


	Officials said the storm was three times larger than a storm  
spotted 20 years ago by the Viking Orbiter spacecraft. 


	Astronomers used a wide field planetary camera on Hubble to  
photograph Mars during the planet's closest approach to Earth in 
nearly eight years. 


	Two pictures, taken six hours apart on April 27, showed that the  
storm moved slightly eastward. In the second picture, the storm 
appeared to be in the process of breaking up. 


	Later pictures by the Hubble camera failed to find the storm,  
and astronomers said it could have been a short-lived phenomenon.

results.content:
1999-04-28 10:05:16 
 washington 
 NASA's X-ray Telescope Grounded 


	CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (AP) -- NASA's $1.5 billion Chandra X-ray  
telescope will remain stuck on Earth several extra weeks because of 
an Air Force investigation into a stranded satellite. 


	The telescope was supposed to soar aboard space shuttle Columbia  
on July 9. NASA officials said Wednesday that the launch is off 
until at least the end of July. 


	NASA wants to wait until the Air Force's investigation is  
complete before proceeding with the Chandra launch. The mission 
already is a year late because of bad circuit boards that had to be 
replaced in the telescope and other problems. 


	Each month's delay costs NASA $6 million to $8 million, said  
agency spokesman Dave Drachlis. 


	Earlier this month, the Air Force impounded the upper-stage  
motor intended for the telescope. It's the same kind of motor that 
apparently malfunctioned April 9 and left the military's newest 
Defense Support Program satellite in a useless orbit. 


	The Air Force eventually released the upper-stage motor for  
launch preparations, but NASA decided this week to hold off on 
attaching it to the telescope. What, if anything, the Air Force had 
learned from impounding the motor was not disclosed. 


	Air Force spokeswoman Patsy Bomhoff said Wednesday that  
controllers still were working with the stranded DSP satellite and 
had made ``great strides'' in trying to salvage it. But she said it 
will never reach the intended 22,300-mile-high orbit. 


	As for Chandra, it's come a long way despite the latest trouble,  
said Ed Weiler, head of NASA's space science program. 


	``It's been delayed now, what, almost a year,'' he said. ``I can  
guarantee you one thing. Every `i' and `t' is going to be dotted 
and crossed before this thing is launched.'' 


	Chandra, a Hubble-caliber observatory, should have rocketed into  
orbit last August. Unlike Hubble, the X-ray telescope will be 
placed in an orbit too high to be reached by spacewalking 
astronauts so it will be irreparable once launched.

results.content:
1998-01-17 
 British Scientists Make Test Tube Aurora 


LONDON, January 16 (Xinhua) -- British scientists announced
today that they've actually produced an aurora, the phenomenon
usually observed at the Earth's north and south poles, in the lab.


The results, achieved by researchers at University College
London (UCL), bear a striking resemblance to images seen on giant
planets, the UCL said in a statement.


Auroras on earth are formed when fast-moving electrons, thrown
out in the solar wind from the Sun, hit the Earth's upper
atmosphere.


In the experiment, which carried out in a vacuum chamber,
electrons from a filament are accelerated towards a charged sphere
which imitates the Earth.


Inside the sphere is a magnetic coil which, when switched on,
concentrates light towards the "poles" just like a real aurora.


The experiment also shows how magnetized planets are shielded
from solar winds by their magnetic fields which, in turn, funnel
electrons into high latitude auroral zones to create the aurora
effect.


Pictures produced recently by the Hubble space telescope show
that auroras are also available on the planet of Jupiter and
Saturn.


"The results from this experiment will throw more light on how
Saturn's aurora forms," said Dr Andrew Coates, who leads the
aurora lab project at UCL's Mullard Space Science Laboratory.

results.content:
1999-07-24 04:30:09 
 usa 
 Astronauts Use Smaller Observatory 


	SPACE CENTER, Houston (AP) -- With the world's most powerful  
X-ray telescope safely set adrift, the crew of space shuttle 
Columbia today began using a smaller, onboard observatory to gather 
images of planets inside Earth's solar system. 


	Astronaut Steven Hawley took ultraviolet snapshots of Jupiter  
using the Southwest Ultraviolet Imaging System, a telescope-camera 
combination. 


	Columbia's five crew members turned their attention to the  
small, onboard observatory and a handful of secondary experiments 
after successfully completing their primary objective: releasing 
the $1.5 billion Chandra Observatory within hours of liftoff early 
Friday. 


	A rocket motor then propelled Chandra into an elliptical orbit  
that eventually will have a high point of 87,000 miles, or 
one-third of the way to the moon. 


	Shuttle commander Eileen Collins, the first woman to lead a U.S.  
space mission, said she was ``extremely happy'' when she and her 
crew reached orbit and even happier when the Chandra X-ray 
Observatory set off on its mission Friday. 


	As for her place in space history, Collins told a TV  
interviewer: ``I guess I'll have to worry about history a little 
bit later. I'm just happy that we pulled this mission off. We still 
have a few more days, so the pressure isn't off yet. But we've got 
a bunch of happy people up here.'' 


	The telescope release went flawlessly, unlike the shuttle's  
8 1/2-minute climb to orbit seven hours earlier. A short circuit five 
seconds into the flight knocked out a controller on two of the 
three main engines; backup controllers immediately took over on the 
engines. 


	Collins, an Air Force colonel, said she felt ``very confident''  
throughout liftoff, in large part because the problem resembled 
what had been thrown at her during practice sessions on the ground 
in the months and years leading up to the flight. 


	The electrical problem is not expected to affect the rest of the  
five-day shuttle mission, Collins said. Columbia is set to land at 
Kennedy Space Center in Florida late Tuesday. 


	The smaller, onboard imaging system being used by Hawley, an  
astronomer as well as an astronaut, is considered a complement to 
larger observatories like Chandra and the Hubble Space Telescope 
because of its ability to look at objects close to the sun. 


	The system was first used in August 1997 to capture more than  
400,000 images of the Hale-Bopp comet, which the Hubble could not 
observe at times because the sun's glare obscured it. 


	Though less sensitive than the Hubble, the ultraviolet system  
also has a field of view about 30 times wider than its bigger 
cousin. 


	Over the course of Columbia's mission, Hawley is expected to  
gather images of Mercury, Venus and Earth's moon. He is also set to 
use the telescope-camera to search for evidence of vulcanoids, a 
belt of small, asteroid-like bodies which scientists believe 
encircles Mercury. 


	Meanwhile, ground controllers finished powering up Chandra's  
instruments late Friday. Next up for the 45-foot telescope is a 
small rocket burn tonight to adjust its orbit, the first of several 
such corrections over the next nine days. 


	After three to four weeks of instrument calibrations, Chandra  
will transmit its first images back to Earth.

open questions have been answered,'' said payload manager Scott

electricity-generating solar panels.

get it into its proper orbit.''

results.content:
1997-10-08 
 Brightest Star Found in Milky Way 


WASHINGTON, October 8 (Xinhua) -- The Hubble Space Telescope in
Los Angeles has captured a glimpse of what is believed to be most
powerful star ever detected at the core of the Milky Way which
pumps out 10 million times more energy than the sun.


It releases as much energy in six seconds as the sun does in a
whole year, said the research team at the University of California
at Los Angeles on Tuesday.


The Pistol Star was first observed in the early 1990s by
astronomers in South Africa and Japan using Earth-based infrared
telescopes. But Hubble captured the images on September 13 and 14
and realized that it was powerful. The research team released the
images Tuesday before they could publish their findings.


Researchers estimate that the Star is 25,000 light-years from
Earth, near the center of the Milky Way. It has an estimated
radius of 165 million to 235 million kilometers. The sun has a
radius of 722,000 kilometers and is 165 million kilometers from
Earth.


The astronomers estimate the Pistol Star formed 1 million to 3
million years ago and could have been 200 times more massive than
the sun back then.

results.content:
Astronomers capturing images from the Hubble Space telescope
have detected a monstrous cyclone raging over a vast area of Mars,
and they predicted &LR;  that more storms are likely to develop now that
Martian summertime is warming the planet's northern hemisphere.


   The storm system near the North Pole of Mars covered an area
four times larger than the state of Texas, the astronomers said _
but because the upper atmosphere of Mars is so thin, it apparently
kicked up little, if any, dust from the surface.


   The fierce storm was first detected April 27 and continued to
blow for at least three days, said Jim Bell, the Cornell University
astronomer who led the team that tracked it. Bell observed it again
six hours after the telescope transmitted the first sign of the
storm, and it seemed to be already dissipating, he said in an
interview Wednesday.


   The Hubble telescope flies in Earth orbit at an altitude of 300
miles, but despite its superb ability to observe planets, stars and
galaxies at high resolution, it cannot determine the speed of a
windstorm. Bell estimated that at its height, the cyclone's winds
must have been swirling at 200 miles an hour or more.


   Analysis of the storm cloud's spectrum indicated that the winds
were composed of clouds of water ice like similar storm systems on
Earth. The water originated in the ice cap of the North Pole, and
apparently rose after the frozen carbon dioxide that makes up most
of the cap had dissipated as the planet warmed under the summer
sun.


   Warming is only relative, however, because the surface
temperature of the polar cap is now roughly a frigid 9 degrees
Fahrenheit, although the temperature of the upper atmosphere where
the storm winds blow is a far colder 100 degrees below zero, Bell
said.


   The large difference in temperature between the polar cap and
the planet's summertime upper atmosphere is what probably created a
low-pressure vortex, with rising air causing clouds to form _ a
phenomenon similar to hurricanes on Earth, the Hubble scientists
said.


   The huge cyclone, they noted, was very different from the dust
storms that frequently rage over the surface of Mars. Dust storms
were first observed by the Mariner 9 spacecraft in 1971 when one
violent cloud of sandy dust obscured the view from the orbiting
spacecraft's cameras and took more than three weeks to settle.


   In 1977, the Pathfinder spacecraft on Mars also encountered
brief sandstorms, but weather instruments atop its slender mast
clocked the surface winds at only 20 miles an hour.


   The Viking orbiter spacecraft of 1976, which maintained contact
with two Mars landers on the surface in a vain search for evidence
of living organisms, also detected three cyclonic windstorms in the
Martian atmosphere, but the recent huge windstorm that Bell and his
team discovered was at least three times larger, he said.


   The newest cyclone's ``eye'' was nearly 200 miles in diameter.
The entire storm covered an area nearly 1,100 miles across and 900
miles long _ larger than the entire North polar ice cap itself,
Bell said. The planet should see more similar storms over the next
few months during the Martian summer, he said. &LR;

results.content:
NASA PLANS REPAIR MISSION FOR HUBBLE TELESCOPE 




   HOUSTON _ Astronauts will make an emergency shuttle flight to
the $3.8 billion Hubble Space Telescope in mid-October to replace
failing components in the mechanism that points the large
observatory at distant stars, NASA said Wednesday.


   Working from the shuttle Discovery, four veteran astronauts will
make three to four spacewalks to replace all six of the Hubble's
gyroscopes and make other repairs. All four astronauts have been in
training since mid-1998 for a Hubble servicing mission that had
been scheduled for June 2000.


   However, without an expedited visit by a shuttle repair crew,
NASA could be forced to call a halt to Hubble observations, said Ed
Weiler, NASA's chief space scientist. Those observations have
included faint galaxies on the frontiers of the universe, stellar
nurseries, black holes and other mysterious objects that have
become the hallmark of Hubble activities for the past nine years.


   The spin of the gyroscopes enables the telescope's computers and
other electronics to accurately point the telescope. Weiler and
others responsible for the 13-ton, five-story observatory stressed
that the spacecraft is in no danger of drifting away or plunging
through the atmosphere.


   ``This is not a so-called spacecraft emergency,'' Weiler said.
``We think of this as more of a science emergency.''


   At least three of the gyroscopes must spin to maintain the
three-dimensional reference in space required by the telescope to
point precisely.


   Two gyroscopes have failed since the most recent visit to the
the telescope by shuttle astronauts in February 1997. A third
gyroscope faltered Jan. 25, and has been placed in a standby mode,
leaving the minimum needed for observations.


   Telescope engineers calculate an 80 percent likelihood of a
fourth failure if the National Aeronautics and Space Administration
waits until mid-2000 to send a shuttle crew.


   Experts have traced the problem to breaks in the two hair-thin
wires of copper and silver that supply electricity to the spin
motor of each gyroscope.


   ``Right now, the telescope is working just fine and we see no
day-to-day impact in our normal science operations from any of
these issues with the gyroscopes,'' said David Leckrone, the
Hubble's senior project scientist at NASA's Goddard Space Flight
Center in Greenbelt, Md.


   But with the loss of a fourth gyroscope, ground control teams
would be forced to begin to curtail observations. When it finally
fails, the telescope will slip into an electronic slumber called
``safe mode.''


   All of the gyroscopes are at least 11-years-old and the oldest
is 14-years-old. Two of the three fully functioning gyroscopes are
among those originally installed on the telescope.


   NASA believes the mission will take nine days.


   The seven months it has to prepare for the flight will be the
shortest for any it has attempted, and there is a possibility NASA
could advance the launch into late September. The commander, pilot
and robot arm operator will be named later this week, joining the
spacewalking team of Mike Foale, John Grunsfeldand Steve Smith of
the United States, and Claude Nicollier of Switzerland.


   ``This flight will be a challenge, I can tell you that,'' said
NASA's Linda Ham, who will serve as the lead flight director for
the mission.


   Following a rendezvous at 360 miles above the Earth, the 50-foot
shuttle arm will be used to grab Hubble and carefully mount it on a
work platform in Discovery's cargo bay.


   In addition to the gyroscopes, the spacewalkers will install a
new flight computer on the telescope as well as a data recorder and
transmitter. They also are prepared to replace reflective
insulation on the exterior of the Hubble, which is deteriorating
from its long exposure to corrosive elements in the Earth's upper
atmosphere and to radiation.


   The exterior damage was a surprise when first detected by
shuttle astronauts who last visited the space telescope in February
1997. Smith was among them and participated in mak

results.content:
2 ASTRONAUTS BEGIN REPAIR OF HUBBLE SPACE TELESCOPE 



   HOUSTON _ A pair of spacewalking astronauts on Wednesday began
the intricate process of repairing the dormant Hubble Space
Telescope, replacing the faulty gyroscopes that forced the
observatory into hibernation last month.


   With one astronaut standing on the end of the shuttle
Discovery's 50-foot robot arm and the other hooked to the
telescope, the men used power wrenches and other tools to
laboriously pull out three boxes that each contained two of
Hubble's six stabilizing gyroscopes and replace them with new
units.


   Kyle Herring, a spokesman for Mission Control here at the
Johnson Space Center, said the three new units containing the
crucial gyroscopes necessary to point and steady the telescope had
been activated and seemed to be working properly.


   ``All appears at this point to be in good shape with Hubble
essentially back in business,'' Herring said.


   The astronauts, Steven L. Smith and John M. Grunsfeld, started
the first of three planned spacewalks at 1:54 p.m., about an hour
earlier than scheduled to tackle the most important and difficult
part of the repair mission.


   Stepping out of an airlock as the shuttle Discovery passed over
Australia, Smith, a veteran spacewalker who has flown on two
previous shuttle missions, said to his colleague, ``You ready to
go?'' and added, ``Hubble needs us.''


   Grunsfeld, a physicist on his third shuttle flight but a novice
spacewalker, said ``Beautiful sight out here'' as he stepped into
Discovery's cargo bay. ``Hello Hubble,'' he said looking up at the
43-foot observatory towering above him, ``That's one beautiful
telescope.''


   Hubble has been out of commission since Nov. 13, when a fourth
gyroscope failed, rendering the telescope incapable of holding
steady enough to conduct scientific observations. The observatory
powered down and went into a protective ``safe mode'' awaiting its
orbital repair crew.


   Working from lockers in the payload bay that contain scores of
tools and replacement parts, the astronauts repeatedly carried new
equipment up to the 25,000-pound telescope secured to a cradle
above and brought down old parts that will be returned to Earth for
examination.


   After the gyroscope exchange, which took about an hour longer
than expected, the spacewalk team moved to open valves on a cooling
unit attached to a disabled infrared camera to purge nitrogen
coolant. This was to prepare the camera unit, inoperative because
of an earlier coolant leak, for a replacement cooling device to be
installed on a service mission set for 2001. The astronauts
initially could not remove caps covering the valves, but later
forced them off and completed the task.


   Next, Smith and Grunsfeld installed voltage regulator kits on
Hubble's six aging batteries. The six Voltage-Temperature
Improvement Kits were designed to improve the batteries' efficiency
while keeping them from overcharging and overheating during periods
of low power use.


   On Thursday, a team made up of the NASA astronaut C. Michael
Foale and Claude Nicollier of the European Space Agency is to
conduct the second spacewalk starting in the early afternoon.


   The astronauts are to replace Hubble's central computer with a
new, faster model and exchange one of the telescope's three Fine
Guidance Sensors with a refurbished unit. These sensors let the
telescope locked onto a target for hours or days at a time.

results.content:
1999-03-10 15:25:12 
 usa 
 NASA To Fix Hubble Telescope 


 *NASA to launch emergency repair trip to telescope    	


	CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (AP) -- NASA will launch an emergency repair  
mission this fall to the Hubble Space Telescope, which is in danger 
of shutting down. 


	NASA decided Wednesday to move up the next regularly scheduled  
Hubble visit to October so that spacewalking astronauts can fix the 
telescope's deteriorating pointing system. The mission had been set 
for June 2000. 


	Two of Hubble's six gyroscopes, needed for pointing and  
stability, have failed since astronauts' last service call, in 
1997. And a third gyroscope is partly broken and is considered 
unreliable. 


	Astronomers need at least three perfect gyroscopes to conduct  
observations throughout the universe. 


	``We are one failure away from losing science,'' said Ed Weiler,  
head of NASA's space science program. 


	Although the $2 billion telescope would be safe in orbit without  
any working gyroscopes, NASA does not want to risk losing any 
valuable science time. 


	``This is not a so-called spacecraft emergency where we're in  
danger of losing the entire mission or the entire spacecraft,'' 
Weiler said. ``You can think of it more as a science emergency.'' 


	Under the plan, the original 2000 mission will be divided into  
two parts: the first will be launched around mid-October aboard 
Discovery and the second in late 2000 or early 2001. 


	Besides replacing all six gyroscopes in October, spacewalking  
astronauts will install a new computer, radio transmitter, guidance 
sensor and data recorder, and fix peeling insulation. 


	During their second visit, the same astronauts will equip Hubble  
with new solar panels, an advanced camera and a newfangled cooling 
unit for an infrared camera that has run out of the frozen nitrogen 
needed for observations. 


	The four astronauts who will do the repairs have been training  
since last summer and can easily accommodate the early flight, NASA 
said. 


	The extra mission will cost NASA $75 million more than what's  
been budgeted for Hubble. But Weiler called it ``a rather good 
insurance policy'' considering the science that might be lost if 
NASA were to wait until next summer to make the repairs. 


	Hubble was launched in 1990 with a misshapen mirror.  
Spacewalking astronauts corrected the telescope's vision in 1993, 
restoring Hubble to a world-class instrument able to see to the 
fringes of the universe, and returned in 1997 to add or replace 11 
major parts. 


	NASA will have to rearrange the shuttle flight schedule to  
squeeze in the Hubble mission. Those details have yet to be worked 
out.
