results.content:
NASA SHUTTLE MISSION IS MOVED UP TO REPAIR HUBBLE TELESCOPE



   WASHINGTON _ Seeking to avoid a ``science emergency'' with the
Hubble Space Telescope, NASA officials announced Wednesday that
they would launch a space shuttle to repair failing parts on the
orbiting observatory in mid-October, eight months ahead of
schedule.


   National Aeronautics and Space Administration officials said the
shuttle Discovery and a team of spacewalking astronauts would be
dispatched to replace malfunctioning gyroscopes that stabilize
Hubble and allow the 12.5-ton telescope to point accurately at
targets across the universe.


   Edward J. Weiler, NASA's associate administrator for science,
said at a news conference that the $2 billion telescope itself was
not in danger, but its scientific mission was threatened by the
malfunctioning pointing devices.


   ``This is not a spacecraft emergency,'' Weiler said, ``it's more
of a science emergency.''


   Hubble, which has regularly uncovered the mysteries of the
cosmos since its launching in 1990, ``is the crown jewel of NASA's
space observatories,'' said Weiler, and every reasonable effort
must be made to keep it functioning. While the telescope is now
operating normally, he said, only three of its six gyroscopes are
working properly, the minimum needed for it to perform its
observations.


   Two gyroscopes have failed and a third is acting so abnormally
that it cannot be relied upon as a backup. If one of the three
functioning gyroscopes fails in coming months, Weiler said, Hubble
will have to cease its science mission and go into a protective
``safe mode'' until replacement parts are installed.


   ``We are one failure away from losing all science from the
Hubble Space Telescope,'' Weiler said.


   Officials said the risk of losing months of invaluable Hubble
data, wasting about $20 million per month budgeted for these
observations, made it worth spending extra money for an early
service mission. The October shuttle mission will add an extra $25
million to Hubble program costs over two years and $50 million to
shuttle program costs over the same period, officials said.


   Under the new plan, the Hubble service mission scheduled for
June 2000 will be split into two parts, with about half of the
planned modifications and equipment changes being carried out in
October during a nine-day flight. In addition to replacing all six
of Hubble's gyroscopes, astronauts are to exchange the
observatory's central computer with a faster, new model; add a new
fine-guidance sensor; replace an old-style data tape recorder with
a digital model, and change a backup radio transmitter.


   A second mission to upgrade Hubble's scientific equipment,
during which a powerful new camera will be added to look at small
objects and the solar power arrays will be replaced, will be flown
between December 2000, and March 2001.


   William Readdy, an astronaut who is the shuttle program
director, said the same four astronauts who were training to do
spacewalks for the original service assignment would fly on both
segments of the divided mission. They are Steven L. Smith, C.
Michael Foale, John M. Grunsfeld and Claude Nicollier. The
remaining crew members, a commander, a pilot and a flight engineer,
will be announced by the end of the week, Readdy said.


   It normally takes more than a year to plan a shuttle mission,
Readdy said, but the flight to Hubble can be put together quickly
because most of the crew is far along in training for it.

1999-05-16 09:11:18 
 usa 
 NASA Prepares To Repair Telescope 


	CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (AP) -- Anxiety is high as NASA prepares for  
a rush repair job on its beloved Hubble Space Telescope. 


	Hubble's pointing system could die any day, halting all  
astronomical observations. So NASA is sending astronauts to the 
rescue in October, eight months earlier than they were supposed to 
go. 


	The spacewalkers will not only install new gyroscopes for  
precision pointing, they will replace Hubble's brain -- its main 
computer -- and patch Hubble's peeling skin. 


	``It's got this added drama to it,'' says Steven Smith, a  
veteran Hubble repairman who will lead the spacewalking team. 
``Anytime you're working toward a goal and it becomes more urgent, 
it's a little bit more exciting. 


	``But on the down side, something's wrong with this national  
asset. That's bad, and there are thousands of people in the United 
States who are going to have to work a lot harder than they were 
going to have to originally work in the next five months to get us 
ready.'' 


	NASA has never put together a shuttle mission so fast.  


	Smith and the three other astronauts assigned as spacewalkers  
have been training since August. But the flight crew was not chosen 
until March, a few days after NASA decided to split the originally 
scheduled June 2000 repair mission into two. 


	The first thing newly appointed commander Curtis Brown Jr. told  
his crew was: ``Grab ahold of something, because here we go! We 
only have 28 weeks to launch and we have all the training to get 
done.'' 


	Brown is confident they'll be ready for an Oct. 14 liftoff  
aboard space shuttle Discovery. Three and possibly four spacewalks 
are planned for the nine-day mission. 


	``Out of seven people on board, we have 18 shuttle flights. We  
have a lot of experience on board,'' says Brown, an Air Force 
officer who will be making a record-tying sixth shuttle flight. 


	NASA managers as well as astronomers around the world are  
keeping their fingers crossed that the $2 billion telescope will 
keep operating until Brown and his crew get there. The mission 
cannot be pushed up any earlier, even if something else breaks. 


	``There's an edge (of tension), but we haven't shortcut anything  
so far,'' says John Campbell, NASA's associate director for the 
Hubble Space Telescope. ``That's why I'm unwilling to move it any 
earlier. Then I feel we'd have to start shortcutting.'' 


	The problem is with Hubble's gyroscopes, needed to aim the  
telescope and hold it steady as it scrutinizes the universe. Three 
of the six have failed because of corroded wires. One more failure 
and astronomical observations will cease, although the telescope 
itself will be safe in orbit. 


	``If you believe the statisticians -- and I don't -- they say  
there's a 70 percent chance we'll make it to October,'' says Ed 
Weiler, head of NASA's space science program. 


	That's why Weiler and other scientists consider this an  
emergency mission. 


	Commander Brown bristles, however, at that description.  


	``Let me start my crusade right now,'' he tells an interviewer.  
``This is not an emergency mission, OK? This is a science mission 
and a repair mission and it's not an emergency mission. 


	``If another gyro fails right now as we speak, Hubble would go  
into a safe mode and the Hubble Telescope would be perfectly fine 
until we got up there. It's not going to hurt itself or anything.'' 


	For now, the three working gyroscopes show no signs of  
degradation. (Two are originals, launched with the telescope back 
in 1990.) But the wire corrosion that knocked out the three other 
gyroscopes seems to occur at random with little, if any, advance 
warning. 


	All six gyroscopes will be replaced with improved units during  
the upcoming mission. (They come two to a pack.) Smith and his 
spacewalking partners also will install a new computer, radio 
transmitter, guidance sensor and data recorder, and fix some of the 
tattered thermal insulation.

results.content:
1999-02-24 17:59:38 
 washington 
  NASA May Repair Hubble Telescope 


	WASHINGTON (AP) -- Mechanical problems that threaten to shut down  
the astronomical observations of the Hubble Space Telescope may 
prompt a repair mission six months earlier than planned to the $1.7 
billion spacecraft, NASA officials told Congress on Wednesday. 


	The problem is ailing gyroscopes, said Daniel Goldin, the  
administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. 
Gyroscopes are used for the stability and fine pointing the Hubble 
needs to gather light from stars billions of light years away. 


	The loss of all gyroscopes would mean the space telescope could  
not make astronomical observations, but it would not threaten the 
spacecraft, officials said. Instead, the failure of the gyros would 
cause the craft to go into an automatic ``safe mode'' until the 
repairs are made. 


	The Hubble was launched in 1990 and immediately had problems.  
Astronomers discovered that the 2.4-meter mirror on the telescope 
had been ground to the wrong curvature and the instrument, in 
effect, was nearsighted. 


	But a new set of optics installed by astronauts in 1993  
corrected the problem. And since then, the Hubble has made 
photographs of tens of thousands of previously unseen galaxies, 
giving unprecedented views of the heavens. Some of the stellar 
targets are more than 13 billion light years away, near the 
theoretical edge of the universe. The Hubble was designed to remain 
operational until 2010. 


	The Hubble needs three gyroscopes to work properly and it has  
lost two of its six. Another gyro ``is sick and may go down in 
three months,'' Goldin said. 


	If the Hubble loses a fourth gyro, it will have to be shut down  
until a space shuttle crew goes up to the orbiting telescope and 
installs a new set of gyroscopes, he said. A decision about an 
emergency mission is expected no later than next week. 


	For practical planning, the spacecraft is already on the edge of  
losing gyroscope control because one of the remaining four control 
instruments ``is quite ill,'' said David S. Leckrone, senior 
project scientist for the telescope. 


	``If another gyro fails, we would not put the fourth gyro back  
into service,'' he said, meaning that the Hubble is only one 
failure away from being shut down. 


	The problem is in wires that carry power to the rapidly spinning  
gyroscopes. The gyros can operate on either of the two wires, but 
when one wire breaks, it causes an increase in voltage carried by 
the other. 


	In earlier gyroscope failures, engineers saw a sudden increase  
in voltage carried by one wire. Within weeks, that wire also 
failed. One wire has already failed in the ailing gyro, said 
Leckrone. 


	Should all of Hubble's gyroscopes shut down, he said, the  
spacecraft would switch automatically to a safe mode that keeps its 
solar power array pointed at the sun. As long as the craft is 
powered by the sun, engineers on the ground can control it. 


	NASA already had planned for a June 2000, Hubble servicing  
mission that would include replacing all of the gyroscopes, along 
with a computer and some other instruments. But Leckrone said he 
and others at the Goddard Spaceflight Center have proposed that an 
emergency mission be flown this October to change out the ailing 
gyros, and that the rest of the serving be done on a mission in 
2001. 


	An earlier servicing mission to change cameras and other  
equipment was flown in 1997, and a final servicing mission is 
planned for 2003.

results.content:
GOTCHA! SPACE SHUTTLE CREW CAPTURES BROKEN TELESCOPE



   HOUSTON _ After a spirited chase across the sky, the space
shuttle Discovery grabbed the Hubble Space Telescope with its robot
arm Tuesday, retrieving the observatory to begin a critical repair
mission.


   The space shuttle, which had been chasing Hubble since being
launched on Sunday, spent the day closing in on the observatory
from below through a series of rocket firings.


   Lt. Col. Curtis L. Brown of the Air Force, the mission
commander, and Lt. Cmdr. Scott J. Kelley of the Navy, the pilot,
maneuvered the two spacecraft together until they linked up 369
miles above the Gulf of Mexico. At 7:34 p.m. Eastern time,
Jean-Francois Clervoy, the French astronaut operating the shuttle's
50-foot robot arm, snared Hubble as the craft flew in formation at
17,000 mph.


   ``We have a good capture,'' Clervoy said with enthusiasm, ``We
have Hubble grappled.''


   Clervoy slowly lowered the 25,000-pound, 43-foot-long
observatory to a rotating cradle in the Discovery's cargo bay,
where it was latched in place by three clamps for a critical period
of inspection and repair. Hubble has been out of operation for more
than six weeks, since four of six stabilizing gyroscopes failed,
making it impossible for the telescope to lock onto celestial
targets for scientific studies.


   If the much-delayed repair mission, originally scheduled for
October, is successful, scientists hope to have Hubble back in
operation sometime next month.


   Capturing the telescope begins an intensive three days of work
for the seven-man shuttle crew, focusing on three work-packed
spacewalks. The shuttle's weather-delayed launching forced the
National Aeronautics and Space Administration to drop plans for a
fourth spacewalk and compress the original 10-day mission into
eight. NASA wants the shuttle on the ground and all mission
equipment powered down by the end of the year to avoid any computer
problems associated with the year 2000 date change.


   During the first spacewalk, scheduled to begin on Wednesday
afternoon and last six and a half hours, the astronauts Steven L.
Smith and John M. Grunsfeld are to perform the primary repairs of
the mission. The astronauts, one perched at the end of the
shuttle's robot arm, will open the telescope and replace three Rate
Sensor Units, enclosures that each contain two of the critical
gyroscopes needed to point and steady the telescope.


   Working within the close quarters of the telescope, the
astronauts must be careful not to bump or jostle Hubble's delicate
optics and other instruments while making the equipment switches.


   Also, insulating material inside and outside the telescope is
aging and becoming brittle, posing the risk of debris that could
get into the observatory and damage instruments.


   ``We certainly don't want to rub up against it because it would
create little particles,'' Smith said before the flight.


   After replacing the six gyroscopes, the astronauts are to
install voltage regulator kits on Hubble's six aging batteries to
keep them from overcharging and overheating in periods of low power
use. They will also service a valve on an instrument cooling
system.


   On Thursday, C. Michael Foale, a NASA astronaut, and Claude
Nicollier, a European Space Agency astronaut, are to take more than
six hours for several tasks, including the replacement of Hubble's
central computer with a new model, which is more than 20 times
faster and has six times the memory of the current one. The
spacewalkers then will swap one of the telescope's three Fine
Guidance Sensors with a refurbished unit. These devices allow the
telescope to remain locked on a target for hours or days at a time.


   Linda Ham, the lead flight director for the mission, said NASA
could call the mission completely successful if the astronauts
completed the tasks planned for the first two spacewalks.
``Anything after that is added value,'' Ms. Ham said.


   On the third spacewalk, set for Friday, Smith and Grunsfeld are
to replace a failed radio transmitter and install

results.content:
1999-03-10 22:25:48 
 usa 
 NASA To Fix Hubble Telescope 


	CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (AP) -- Astronauts will rush to the Hubble  
Space Telescope this fall -- eight months early -- to fix its 
deteriorating pointing system. 


	NASA approved the emergency repair mission on Wednesday.  


	``We are one failure away from losing all science on the Hubble  
Space Telescope,'' said Ed Weiler, head of NASA's space science 
program. 


	By splitting the originally planned June 2000 mission into two  
parts -- one in October and the other in late 2000 or early 2001 -- 
Hubble's science program hopefully will be preserved and the 
astronauts' chores will be more manageable, Weiler said. 


	``If we had waited until June 2000, there is a very reasonable  
chance that we could lose three, four or even more months of 
science,'' Weiler said. ``This is a rather good insurance policy 
we're buying here.'' 


	The extra mission will cost NASA $75 million more than what's  
already been budgeted. 


	Two of Hubble's six gyroscopes, needed for pointing and  
stability, have failed since astronauts' last service call, in 
1997. And a third gyroscope suffered a partial breakdown a month or 
two ago and is considered unreliable. 


	Astronomers need at least three perfect gyroscopes to conduct  
observations throughout the universe. 


	Although the $2 billion telescope would be safe in orbit without  
any working gyroscopes, NASA does not want to risk losing any 
valuable science time. 


	``This is not a so-called spacecraft emergency where we're in  
danger of losing the entire mission or the entire spacecraft,'' 
Weiler said. ``You can think of it more as a science emergency.'' 


	Hubble -- NASA's so-called crown jewel of observatories -- was  
launched in 1990 with a misshapen mirror. Spacewalking astronauts 
corrected the telescope's vision in 1993, restoring Hubble to a 
world-class instrument able to see to the fringes of the universe, 
and returned in 1997 to add or replace 11 major parts. 


	Besides replacing all six gyroscopes in October, spacewalking  
astronauts will install a new computer, radio transmitter, guidance 
sensor and data recorder, and fix peeling insulation. 


	During their second visit, the same astronauts will equip Hubble  
with new solar panels, an advanced camera and a newfangled cooling 
unit for an infrared camera that has run out of the frozen nitrogen 
needed for observations. 


	The four astronauts who will do the repairs have been training  
since last summer and can easily accommodate the early flight, 
officials said. One of the four worked on Hubble in 1997. 


	NASA will have to rearrange the shuttle flight schedule to  
squeeze in the Hubble mission. Those details have yet to be worked 
out.

results.content:
HUBBLE TELESCOPE TO GET BILLION-MILE TUNEUP 




   Perhaps the world's best-known astronomical observatory, the
orbiting Hubble Space Telescope is no stranger to NASA's
spacewalking repairmen.


   And Thursday, for the third time since the telescope was
launched in 1990, an expedition of shuttle astronauts will set out
to grab the observatory from its perch in space. Their objective is
to replace a half-dozen gyroscopes, key components in the
telescope's pointing system, and to make other repairs.


   The 43-foot-long telescope is the only unmanned spacecraft NASA
has developed that was designed for periodic visits by astronauts,
to upgrade large cameras and other scientific instruments and to
replace worn-out parts.


   A gyroscope failure, the fourth since the last repair mission,
forced astronomers to halt observations with the telescope Nov. 13,
lending new urgency to the much-delayed shuttle flight.


   ``These gyros in Hubble are the most accurate ever produced,''
said Ed Weiler, NASA's associate administrator for space science.
``They are required to get the kind of science we get from Hubble.
Without those gyros, those stars would be just fuzzy points of
light.''


   Liftoff is scheduled for 9:18 p.m. EST Thursday from Cape
Canaveral, Fla. If Discovery takes off, the seven astronauts plan
to gently grab the 13-ton telescope with Discovery's 50-foot robot
arm and berth it upright in the shuttle's cargo bay for the repair
sessions.


   During four lengthy spacewalks, alternating teams of astronauts
will install new gyros and a faster flight computer, and replace
both an out-of-date recorder used to store images and a broken
transmitter used to relay those images to EarthAs time permits, the spacewalkers will patch parts of Hubble's
external covering damaged by solar radiation.


   ``The Hubble is the best example ever of the successful marriage
of the human space program and space science,'' said Weiler.


   During their first postlaunch repair mission in 1993, shuttle
astronauts corrected an embarrassing optical flaw that escaped
NASA's detection before the telescope was launched. They visited
again in early 1997 to upgrade its observing powers with new
cameras and other equipment.


   Recently, NASA's repair strategy enabled it to extend the
observatory's operational life to 2010, five years beyond the
original plan and long enough to permit the development of an even
more capable successor.


   The extension will push NASA's total Hubble investment to nearly
$6 billion. The space agency estimates the cost of Discovery's
10-day flight at $205 million, including expenses for the telescope
repairs. However, the cost is nearly $400 million if a 1998 NASA
consultant's estimate for the cost of a shuttle flight is applied.


   With nearly 13,000 observations to date, the space telescope has
made remarkable discoveries. It has enabled astronomers to refine
their estimates of the age of the universe at 12 billion years and
to calculate with more certainty that the cosmos will expand
forever.


   Recent images reveal dust discs swirling around a collection of
two dozen young stars, a prelude to the formation of planets,
astronomers believe. Working with other space- and ground-based
observatories, the Hubble has gathered much-sought evidence that
puzzling periodic gamma ray bursts occur in the fringes of the
universe, rather than within the Milky Way galaxy.


   NASA announced the shuttle's latest service call in March to
stem the succession of gyro failures. At the time, only three of
the devices were still functioning, the minimal number needed for
cosmic observations.


   Spinning at 19,200 revolutions per minute, the gyros hold the
large telescope steady so that it can stare at faint stellar
targets for lengthy periods of time.


   Despite its astronaut-friendly design, the telescope is
considered a fragile instrument that must be handled with care to
prevent its precision optics from becoming contaminated or
misaligned.


   ``You watch with your heart in your mouth basically,'' said
NASA's Anne Ki

   WASHINGTON _ The Hubble Space Telescope has temporarily ceased
scientific operations because of the failure of its precision
pointing system, a development that will leave the valuable
observatory dormant until a space-shuttle repair mission scheduled
to arrive next month, NASA officials said Monday.


   The orbiting telescope shut itself down on Saturday when one of
the three remaining gyroscopes used to stabilize and point the
observatory failed after 12 hours of erratic behavior. The
telescope needs a minimum of three of its six gyroscopes operating
to make astronomical observations, and had been limping along on
three of the devices since February.


   Troubled by the threat of losing valuable observations from one
of the world's premier optical telescopes, National Aeronautics and
Space Administration officials decided last March to divide a
Hubble service mission planned for June 2000 and send up a
space-shuttle crew early to install new gyroscopes and do some
other work.


   The 10-day service flight, originally scheduled for mid-October
but delayed because of space-shuttle problems, is tentatively set
for launching on Dec. 6. A second mission, to complete Hubble
modifications planned for the original service and repair flight,
is scheduled for May 2001.


   Dr. David Leckrone of NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in
Greenbelt, Md., the senior project scientist for Hubble, said
Monday that the observatory's shutdown shows the wisdom of last
spring's decision to fly a service mission early. If the shuttle
mission gets off on time and is successful, he said, the loss of
Hubble data will be minimal.


   ``I'm feeling very lucky today,'' Leckrone said in an interview.
``It could have been much worse, and it's gratifying to know that
we made the right call.''


   In announcing the early mission, Dr. Edward Weiler, NASA's chief
scientist, said the agency wanted to avoid a ``science emergency''
in which researchers would lose the service of one of astronomy's
crown jewels. About $20 million a month is budgeted for Hubble
observations, he said, and the $75 million cost of the extra
shuttle service mission was worth the expense to protect this
research investment.


   With only two working gyroscopes, the Hubble automatically went
into ``safe mode,'' a dormant condition in which the telescope
closed its aperture door to protect its optics and aligned itself
to the sun to ensure that its solar panels could draw adequate
power. Ground crews continue to control and monitor the craft when
it is in the safe state, officials said.


   NASA officials said Hubble's shutdown should result in only
three weeks of lost data. Leckrone said about 100 observations had
been scheduled between last weekend and the beginning of the
service mission, at which time the telescope was to have stopped
doing studies for three weeks to a month anyway.


   It should be possible to reschedule most of the lost
observations within the next year, Leckrone said.


   (STORY CAN END HERE _ OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)


   The shuttle Discovery was moved to its launching pad over the
weekend and its seven-member crew is at the Kennedy Space Center in
Florida to rehearse the countdown and launching. Discovery's flight
was delayed because testing and modifications to all electrical
wiring in all four shuttles took longer than expected, and one of
Discovery's three main engines had to be changed after a servicing
accident.


   The primary task of the mission is to replace all six of
Hubble's gyroscopes, which are packaged in pairs. Four new
gyroscopes were installed during the first Hubble servicing
mission, in 1993, and all six of the instruments were working
during the second service mission, in 1997. One failed later in
1997, a second stopped working in 1998 and a third was lost last
February.

silver-copper wires the size of a human hair that carry electricity
to the high-speed motors that turn the gyroscopes' stabilizing
wheels. The wir

results.content:
SHUTTLE ASTRONAUTS REPLACE HUBBLE COMPUTER 




   HOUSTON _ Spacewalking astronauts from the shuttle Discovery
scaled the towering Hubble Space Telescope on Thursday for a second
time, replacing the observatory's sluggish main computer with a
faster model and finishing repairs to the recently disabled
pointing system.


   As the second spacewalk of Discovery's repair mission to the $4
billion observatory drew to a close, the seven astronauts had
accomplished the tasks NASA considered essential to qualify the
flight a success.


   ``The Hubble Space Telescope is essentially back up to full
capability,'' said NASA spokesman Kyle Herring.


   The astronauts planned a final excursion Friday to make the near
10-year-old observatory even more robust.


   Early Thursday, the six new gyroscopes installed during the
first spacewalk passed an exhaustive test, allowing NASA managers
to declare the repair with the highest priority a success. Crucial
to the precise pointing of the telescope, the new gyros will enable
astronomers to resume the celestial observations halted in
mid-November because of successive failures.


   Voltage regulators installed during the first spacewalk to
prolong the life of the telescope's six aging power storage
batteries passed a thorough checkout as well.


   Astronauts Mike Foale and Claude Nicollier teamed for Thursday's
eight-hour excursion.


   ``Wonderful. Beautiful,'' exclaimed Nicollier, as Discovery
sailed more than 360 miles above the Pacific Ocean. ``It's a great
privilege to work on Hubble for the astronomical community all over
the world.``


   Soon, Foale and Nicollier were perched on the tip of the
shuttle's 55-foot-long robot arm, rising to an equipment bay that
houses the Hubble's main computer at the midsection of the
42-foot-long space telescope.


   The observatory has towered from a berthing mechanism in the
shuttle's cargo bay since the Discovery astronauts rendezvoused
with the telescope Tuesday night.


   Within two-and-a-half hours, Foale and Nicollier had removed the
telescope's original, late 1970s-era computer and replaced it with
a newer model.


   The new $7 million computer has 20 times the processing speed of
the older model and six times its memory.


   Next, Foale assisted Nicollier with another time consuming
repair task.


   Again riding the tip of the shuttle arm, the two spacewalkers
ascended midway up the side of the telescope to replace one of the
observatory's three fine guidance sensors. Like the gyros, the
sensors are crucial to aiming the telescope at celestial targets
and holding it steady.


   Replacing the large sensor proved difficult. A $13 million
replacement wedged out of position as the two spacewalkers tried to
slide it into place. Nicollier and Foale wiggled it free, removed
it and reinserted the sensor without difficulty.


   At one point, concerned ground controllers noted a high carbon
dioxide reading from medical sensors within Nicollier's space suit.


   ``I'm working hard, but I feel fine,'' Nicollier assured mission
control, where experts determined the high readings were probably
coming from an errant sensor. ``I'm just thirsty, but I'm OK.''


   Though Thursday's successful spacewalk completed all of the
major Hubble repair tasks assigned to Discovery's crew, astronauts
Steve Smith and John Grunsfeld will return to the telescope again
Friday during a third and final excursion.


   As an encore to Wednesday's gyro repair, Smith and Grunsfeld
will install a faster data recorder and a new transmitter. Both are
used to store the celestial imagery gathered by the telescope and
relay it to ground-based astronomers.


   The space telescope was launched in 1990. Discovery's is the
third shuttle visit to the telescope, which was developed so that
it could be repaired and equipped with new instruments by
spacewalking astronauts.


   After nearly a decade in orbit, Hubble remains one of the
world's most powerful observatories.


   Astronomers have used it to refine the age of the universe at
about 12 billion years and to bolster

results.content:
SHUTTLE ASTRONAUTS ACCOMPLISH CRUCIAL HUBBLE REPAIRS 




   HOUSTON _ Floating outside the Hubble Space Telescope,
spacewalking astronauts from the shuttle Discovery on Wednesday
accomplished the major task of restoring the observatory's disabled
pointing system.


   The effort is expected to allow scientists next month to resume
studying the frontiers of space. Launched in 1990, Hubble is one of
the world's most powerful astronomical observatories.


   Astronauts Steve Smith and John Grunsfeld replaced the
telescope's six faltering gyroscopes during the spacewalk that
lasted about eight hours.


   The gyro exchange was the most important assignment for
Discovery's eight-day Hubble repair mission that began earlier this
week. The seven-man shuttle crew rendezvoused with the 42-foot-long
telescope late Tuesday, securing it in the ship's cargo bay with
Discovery's robot arm, setting the stage for the first of the
mission's three spacewalks.


   ``All appears at this point to be in good shape, with Hubble now
essentially back in business with six new gyroscopes,'' said NASA
spokesman Kyle Herring, as commands from ground controllers
confirmed a proper installation by the spacewalkers. A more
elaborate evaluation of the work was planned overnight.


   Hubble observations came to a halt in mid-November as the
telescope experienced its fourth gyro failure in two years, sending
the instrument into an electronic slumber. The fast revving
turbines in the small gyroscopes are a crucial component of a
pointing mechanism that enables the 12.5-ton instrument to be aimed
at celestial targets selected by ground-based astronomers with
unprecedented precision.


   ``It's a beautiful sight out here, beautiful day,'' said Smith
as he emerged from Discovery's airlock shortly before 1 p.m. CST to
kick off the first excursion.


   The shuttle sped more than 360 miles over the Pacific Ocean west
of Australia as Smith surveyed his new surroundings.


   ``Hello, Hubble,'' gasped Grunsfeld, who traded a career as an
astronomer to become an astronaut. ``That's a big telescope.''


   The two men purposefully began what was to be a six-hour
spacewalk nearly an hour early. They were hopeful the head start
would enable them to recover some of the repair tasks dropped from
the flight as Discovery lifted off Sunday after a record nine
launch delays. In order to complete the flight before New Year's
Eve and a potential Y2K conflict, mission managers trimmed the
flight from 10 to eight days and cut the number of spacewalks from
four to three.


   The strategy proved wise as the nearly three hours alloted for
the gyro replacement took almost four hours. At times, the men
struggled with the demanding, hand-intensive work.


   The cupboardlike doors of a large enclosure at the base of the
telescope housing the gyros proved difficult for the astronauts to
open, slowing their efforts. Then some of the bolts securing the
three toaster-sized assemblies holding the six gyros resisted the
first efforts by the spacewalkers to remove them.


   ``Got some curve balls, got some knuckle balls today,'' Smith
muttered at one point.


   Working as a team, Smith leaned into the telescope enclosure on
his back, while Grunsfeld held his weightless colleague in place at
the feet. Using battery-powered ratchets, they removed one gyro
assembly and replaced it with a new one before moving to the next.


   Engineers believe the older gyros failed as hair-thin electrical
wires corroded and broke. Five of the six new gyros were modified
to prevent a recurrence. The space agency says it ran out of time
to produce the sixth.


   Smith and Grunsfeld also struggled with a second task, freeing a
pair of small valves to release nitrogen gas from a failed cooling
system for the telescope's infrared camera. Engineers want nitrogen
frozen in the cooling lines to vent away before a replacement
refrigerator is installed during a shuttle visit in mid-2001.


   Alloted 15 minutes, the task took more than 90 minutes.


   Smith and Grunsfeld regained their stride with the ins

DISCOVERY CREW ON ITS WAY TO REPAIR HUBBLE 




   CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. _ The shuttle Discovery rocketed into space
late Sunday with seven astronauts on a much-delayed mission to
repair the high-flying Hubble Space Telescope.


   Discovery thundered from its coastal launch pad at NASA's
Kennedy Space Center at 7:50 p.m. EST. The shuttle climbed steeply
into a darkened sky on an easterly trajectory.


   Minutes later, Discovery settled into a 364-mile-high orbit,
completing the first leg of its Christmas mission to replace
faltering gyroscopes aboard the $4 billion telescope. The
observatory sailed over Africa as Discovery lifted off.


   Originally targeted for a mid-October liftoff, Discovery's
launch had been rescheduled a record nine times by equipment
problems and bad weather. NASA considered Sunday night the final
opportunity to lift off this year.


   ``Send a note to the Hubble to get ready because we are on our
way,'' Discovery commander Curt Brown radioed ground controllers as
the final minutes of Sunday's trouble-free countdown ticked away.


   Hours before the launch, managers agreed to trim the mission
from its original 10 days to eight and the number of spacewalks
from four to three in order to satisfy NASA's Y2K computer
constraints. Discovery is scheduled to land Dec. 27. But if there
are landing delays because of poor weather, the space agency wants
the shuttle crew back on Earth no later than Dec. 29.


   The schedule enables NASA to re-set mission and launch control
computers before New Year's Eve. Though it has prepared Discovery
and its ground facilities to be Y2K compliant, NASA established the
Dec. 29 deadline as a precaution.


   Brown's crew includes pilot Scott Kelly and Jean Francois
Clervoy of the European Space Agency, the flight engineer and robot
arm operator. Accompanying the flight crew is a four-man spacewalk
repair team, Steve Smith, Mike Foale, John Grunsfeld and European
Space Agency astronaut Claude Nicollier.


   With a series of carefully timed orbital maneuvers, Discovery
should overtake the space telescope Tuesday. Using Discovery's
50-foot-long robot arm, Clervoy will snare the 12.5-ton Hubble
shortly before 8 p.m. EST as the spacecraft fly in close formation.


   Once in the shuttle's grasp, the 42-foot-long space telescope
will be latched upright onto a rotating work platform in the aft
section of Discovery's open cargo bay.


   Smith and Grunsfeld plan to kick off the first of the mission's
lengthy spacewalks Wednesday afternoon.


   During the first excursion, the men plan to replace all six of
the Hubble's gyroscopes, the $400 million mission's highest
priority.


   Celestial observations with the space telescope ceased Nov. 13,
when a fourth gyro malfunctioned. Without at least three of the
high-revving devices, the telescope cannot lock on to stellar
objects with precision as it races around the Earth once every 97
minutes.


   With a successful gyro installation, NASA would consider
Discovery's flight at least a minimal success if the other
spacewalks had to be canceled. With the installation of the new
gyros, the space telescope could resume stellar observations in
January, said NASA's Dave Leckrone, the Hubble's senior project
scientist.


   Nevertheless, once the gyro task is complete, Smith and
Grunsfeld plan to install voltage meters on each of the
observatory's six batteries. The cell phone-sized devices are
intended to prolong the life of the 9-year-old batteries by keeping
them from overheating as they age. The batteries are continually
discharged by the telescope's instruments and re-charged by its
power-generating solar arrays.


   During the second spacewalk Thursday, Foale and Nicollier will
team to replace the telescope's flight computer. The newer computer
has six times the memory and is capable of processing data 20 times
faster than its predecessor.


   The two astronauts are also prepared to replace one of the
telescope's three fine guidance sensors, an optical instrument
about the size of a baby grand piano. Like the gyros, the
telesco

results.content:
SPACEWALKERS HAVE A LONG LIST OF REPAIR JOBS FOR THE HUBBLE 




   The shuttle Discovery's spacewalkers have trained to tackle 11
Hubble Space Telescope repair tasks when they reach the observatory
two days after their Thursday launch.


   Replacement of the observatory's half-dozen gyroscopes carries
the highest priority because it would permit stellar observations
to resume. Observations were halted Nov. 13 when a fourth of the
six gyros failed.


   The major tasks include:


   _ The six gyroscopes, paired in three toaster-size electronics
boxes. Only two are working as Discovery prepares to lift off. At
least three are necessary for astronomical observations. NASA would
accept Discovery's mission as a minimal success if the astronauts
depart Hubble with five gyroscopes operating.


   Engineers believe hair-thin internal copper and silver
electrical wires have crumbled from corrosion. Five of the six new
gyros have been assembled with a new technique to eliminate the
corrosion problem. There wasn't time to complete a sixth, NASA
says.


   _ Six voltage improvement kits. These cell phone-size
electronics boxes are designed to keep the half-dozen storage
batteries on Hubble from overheating as they are recharged with
solar power. Nearly 10 years old, the batteries have become more
sensitive to heat as they re-charge.


   _ Flight control computer. Hubble's current computer is based on
1970s technology, though it was augmented with an Intel 386
co-processor in 1993. The portable TV-size replacement incorporates
Intel 486 processors that will increase the processing power by 40
times and enlarge the memory 30-fold. It takes four years to modify
a computer to withstand the higher radiation levels of space,
ruling out a Pentium-class computer on this mission.


   _ Fine guidance sensor. Along with the gyroscopes, the three
fine guidance sensors are a crucial part of the Hubble's pointing
system. One of the baby grand piano-size devices will be replaced.
It works with the flight computer to locate preselected guide stars
that lock the telescope onto its targets. The newest fine guidance
sensor was actually removed in 1997 and refurbished for
re-installation on this mission.


   With the gyroscopes, voltage improvement kits, computer and fine
guidance sensor installed, NASA would call the flight a full
success. However, other tasks are planned.


   _ S-band transmitter, an electronic device that relays digital
imagery data gathered by the telescope to a NASA communications
satellite, which then transmits the information to a NASA ground
station. One of the two original transmitters on the telescope
failed in 1998, though each was expected to last 15 years.


   _ Solid state recorder. The telescope was launched with three
reel-to-reel style data recorders, one of which was replaced by a
solid state device with computer chip data storage during the 1997
repair mission. A second shoe box-size solid state device with a
10-fold improvement in memory capacity will be installed.


   _ External insulation. The metallic outer insulation on Hubble
showed unexpected signs of wear from the corrosive effects of solar
radiation and reactive oxygen molecules in Earth's upper atmosphere
when astronauts visited in 1997.


   The squad of spacewalkers plans to install six new stainless
steel panels over the equipment bays on the telescope. These 3-by-5
panels will help keep internal equipment at room temperature in
spite of external conditions that range from 180 degrees Fahrenheit
in sunlight to minus 130 degrees in darkness.


   _ Release nitrogen gas from the cooling system of the
telescope's infrared camera. Installed by astronauts in 1997, the
frozen nitrogen refrigerant exhausted prematurely in January.
Residues of the gas can be released by an astronaut turning a value
so that a new refrigerant system can be installed on a future
visit.


   _ More external insulation repair. As time permits, the
spacewalkers plan to affix up to seven rolls of flexible metallic
covering to the telescope's light barrel. The longest
wallpap

results.content:
ITS `EYES' SHUT, HUBBLE AWAITS REPAIR 



   WASHINGTON _ Adrift above the Earth, the eye to the universe is
closed. But if all goes according to plan, the Hubble Space
Telescope, a window through which humans have viewed the edges of
space for almost a decade, will soon be reawakened by the nudging,
gloved hands of astronauts replacing and repairing the failed inner
works that forced it into hibernation.


   This weekend, as NASA still struggles to understand the silence
from Mars where the Mars Polar Lander was scheduled to touch down
on Friday, the space shuttle Discovery is scheduled to blast off on
a mission to restore the observatory.


   The telescope has been shut down since Nov. 13, when its
precision pointing system failed and the observatory went dormant.


   During the mission, scheduled to last almost 10 days, Discovery
is to dock with Hubble 300 miles above Earth. Astronauts then
expect to move the telescope into the cargo bay where repairs are
to be made during four six-and-a-half-hour spacewalks.


   The objective is to replace all six gyroscopes, rapidly spinning
devices that use their momentum to stabilize the spacecraft and
help it aim at distant targets. Since February, Hubble had been
getting by on just three gyroscopes, which is the minimum, until
this month, when another failed.


   With only two working gyroscopes, the telescope went into a
``safe mode'' to await repairs. It closed its aperture door to
protect its optics and instruments and aligned its solar panels to
the Sun to assure adequate power.


   The Hubble, which cost $2 billion, was launched in 1990 and,
despite problems with a defective main mirror, has become one of
the most important telescopes in history.


   Looking into space from above the obscuring effects of the
Earth's atmosphere, the 12.5-ton observatory has given astronomers
an unprecedented look at colliding galaxies, star formation and the
remnants of events that occurred early in the history of the
universe.


   NASA has spent $1 billion maintaining and operating Hubble since
it was launched, including developing corrective optics for its
flawed mirror, making second-generation instruments to replace
older ones and sending space shuttles to maintain and repair the
observatory in 1993 and 1997.


   A third service mission had been scheduled for June 2000, but
NASA decided in March that it would move up some of the maintenance
because of the deteriorating gyroscopes.


   Dr. Edward Weiler, associate administrator for space science at
NASA, said the agency decided to schedule an earlier mission to
minimize the loss of observation time with Hubble, which has a
backlog of assignments.


   If repairs by the Discovery crew succeed, officials said, Hubble
will lose about a month of observation time compared with at least
seven months if the agency had stayed with the original schedule.


   To complete all of the maintenance that had been planned for the
flight in June, NASA has scheduled a mission for May 2001, which
will include major upgrades of Hubble's instruments.


   Discovery's flight was originally scheduled for mid-October, but
the mission had been delayed because of assorted problems. A series
of electrical wiring problems required extensive inspection and
repairs, and shuttle managers decided to replace one of Discovery's
three main engines because of an accident while the craft ws being
maintained.


   Ron Dittemore, NASA's shuttle program director, said the agency
has set Dec. 14 as the last date to launch the mission this year.
NASA does not want to be flying on New Year's Day because of the
threat of any possible computer problems caused by the Year 2000
date change. While the agency has tested its computers and
software, Dittemore said, ``It is prudent not to fly if we don't
have to.''


   Crew members said delays in the launching have provided
additional time to train. Keith Johnson, who is in charge of
spacewalk training at the Johnson Space Center in Houston, said the
astronauts were able to complete 10 hours of training in an
underwater tank

results.content:
ON SECOND OUTING, ASTRONAUTS CONTINUE UPGRADE OF TELESCOPE 



   HOUSTON _ The Hubble Space Telescope got smarter and better able
to point at distant astronomical targets on Thursday as
spacewalking astronauts replaced two major pieces of the
observatory's gear.


   On the second spacewalk of the shuttle Discovery's Hubble repair
mission, the astronauts, C. Michael Foale and Claude Nicollier,
swapped out the observatory's central computer and one of its fine
guidance sensors, a precision pointing device.


   The spacewalkers ventured into Discovery's cargo bay, where
Hubble towers almost four stories above, at 2:06 p.m. EST, about 45
minutes earlier than scheduled, to get a jump on their busy day of
replacing some of the telescope's most important components.


   The excursion followed the first spacewalk by Steven L. Smith
and John M. Grunsfeld on Wednesday. They replaced Hubble's six
stabilizing gyroscopes, the focus of the mission, and added
protective devices to the observatory's six aging batteries to
prevent them from overheating and overcharging.


   NASA officials said Thursday that initial tests of the
gyroscopes and the voltage-temperature improvement kits for the
batteries showed that they were properly installed and in good
working order.


   John Campbell, NASA's Hubble program manager, declared the
repair mission's objectives 80 percent complete with the success of
the first spacewalk. Hubble, scheduled to be released by Discovery
on Christmas Day, should be back on the job making scientific
observations about two weeks later, Campbell said.


   In the second of three scheduled spacewalks, Foale and Nicollier
got to work immediately upon exiting the shuttle, which was flying
above Australia at the time.


   For Nicollier, a Swiss astronaut with the European Space Agency
who has flown on three previous shuttle flights, including the
first Hubble service mission in 1993, it was his first spacewalk,
or EVA (for extra-vehicular activity) in NASA terminology.
``Welcome to the EVA fraternity,'' said Smith from inside
Discovery.


   ``It's a great privilege to work on Hubble for the astronomical
community all over the world,'' said Nicollier, an astrophysicist,
after first exclaiming, ``What a view!''


   Foale, a veteran of five previous shuttle flights and two
earlier spacewalks, led the effort to extract Hubble's central
computer while positioned on a workstation at the end of the
shuttle's 50-foot robot arm. It took more than two hours to replace
the computer and move to the next task, but the astronauts soon got
confirmation that they had succeeded when Mission Control said
initial tests showed that the computer was functioning.


   ``The Hubble not only has new brains, it's thinking,'' said
Steven Robinson, mission communicator at the Johnson Space Center
here.


   While the new computer is a big improvement for Hubble, having
20 times the speed and six times the memory of the old one, it is
hardly state-of-the-art by current personal computer standards.


   Hubble's new brain is powered by an Intel 486-DX2 chip running
at a speed of 25 megahertz, a processor long obsolete in desktop
computers now driven by newer Pentium chips. NASA officials said
computer chips used in space must be specially manufactured and
tested to work in that harsh environment, which keeps them
generations behind what is used on Earth.


   ``You have to keep in mind that we don't do Windows, we don't
have disks and we don't do the Internet,'' Campbell explained,
jokingly.


   Following the computer work, the astronauts tackled the
laborious task of exchanging a bulky Fine Guidance Sensor, one of
three optical devices used for precision pointing and measurement.


   The 480-pound device is one that was removed during the second
Hubble servicing mission in 1997 and refurbished.


   With Nicollier working on the robot arm, the spacewalkers
removed an older sensor and tried to slide the new one into place
along a set of guiderails.


   The new unit initially stuck part way into its slot. After
discussion with ground c

minutes earlier than scheduled, to get a jump on their busy day of
replacing some of the telescope's most important components. The
spacewalk lasted 8 hours and 10 minutes.


   The excursion followed the first spacewalk by Steven L. Smith
and John M. Grunsfeld on Wednesday. They replaced Hubble's six
stabilizing gyroscopes, the focus of the mission, and added
protective devices to the observatory's six aging batteries to
prevent them from overheating and overcharging.


   NASA officials said Thursday that initial tests of the
gyroscopes and the voltage-temperature improvement kits for the
batteries showed that they were properly installed and in good
working order.


   John Campbell, NASA's Hubble program manager, declared the
repair mission's objectives 80 percent complete with the success of
the first spacewalk. Hubble, scheduled to be released by Discovery
on Christmas Day, should be back on the job making scientific
observations about two weeks later, Campbell said.


   In the second of three scheduled spacewalks, Foale and Nicollier
got to work immediately upon exiting the shuttle, which was flying
above Australia at the time.


   For Nicollier, a Swiss astronaut with the European Space Agency
who has flown on three previous shuttle flights, including the
first Hubble service mission in 1993, it was his first spacewalk,
or EVA (for extra-vehicular activity) in NASA terminology.
``Welcome to the EVA fraternity,'' said Smith from inside
Discovery.


   ``It's a great privilege to work on Hubble for the astronomical
community all over the world,'' said Nicollier, an astrophysicist,
after first exclaiming, ``What a view!''


   Foale, a veteran of five previous shuttle flights and two
earlier spacewalks, led the effort to extract Hubble's central
computer while positioned on a workstation at the end of the
shuttle's 50-foot robot arm. It took more than two hours to replace
the computer and move to the next task, but the astronauts soon got
confirmation that they had succeeded when Mission Control said
initial tests showed that the computer was functioning.


   ``The Hubble not only has new brains, it's thinking,'' said
Steven Robinson, mission communicator at the Johnson Space Center
here.


   While the new computer is a big improvement for Hubble, having
20 times the speed and six times the memory of the old one, it is
hardly state-of-the-art by current personal computer standards.


   Hubble's new brain is powered by an Intel 486-DX2 chip running
at a speed of 25 megahertz, a processor long obsolete in desktop
computers now driven by newer Pentium chips. NASA officials said
computer chips used in space must be specially manufactured and
tested to work in that harsh environment, which keeps them
generations behind what is used on Earth.


   ``You have to keep in mind that we don't do Windows, we don't
have disks and we don't do the Internet,'' Campbell explained,
jokingly.


   Following the computer work, the astronauts tackled the
laborious task of exchanging a bulky Fine Guidance Sensor, one of
three optical devices used for precision pointing and measurement.


   The 480-pound device is one that was removed during the second
Hubble servicing mission in 1997 and refurbished.


   With Nicollier working on the robot arm, the spacewalkers
removed an older sensor and tried to slide the new one into place
along a set of guiderails.


   The new unit initially stuck part way

results.content:
FAILED GYROSCOPE PUTS HUBBLE INTO SLUMBER; REPAIR MISSION NEXT
MONTH 
 




   HOUSTON _ The fourth of six gyroscopes aboard the orbiting
Hubble Space Telescope has faltered, forcing an abrupt halt to all
celestial observations and lending new urgency to a December space
shuttle repair mission, NASA said Monday.


   Spacewalking astronauts have trained to replace all six of the
gyroscopes and make other repairs during the 10-day flight of the
shuttle Discovery. The shuttle is to lift off with a crew of seven,
including a quartet of spacewalkers, on Dec. 6.


   Saturday's failure left the 13-ton, 43-foot long telescope with
only two operable gyroscopes. At least three are required to carry
out observations of stars, galaxies and other celestial phenomena.


   The high-revving gyroscopes are among the most crucial
components of the telescope's pointing system, which enables
ground-based astronomers to aim and lock the space telescope onto
distant, faint objects for lengthy observations.


   Anticipating additional gyroscope losses, NASA in March
announced an unscheduled servicing call by shuttle astronauts,
weeks after a third Hubble gyroscope faltered. The gyroscopes were
designed for periodic replacement. NASA places the gyroscope
replacement portion of the upcoming $205 million mission at $8
million.


   The next scheduled shuttle visit to Hubble had been planned for
mid-2000. Initially, the agency planned to move the flight to
mid-October, but that changed with the July launching of the
shuttle Columbia with the Chandra X-ray Observatory.


   Moments after liftoff, Columbia experienced an electrical short
that was traced to insulation damage on internal wiring. The
finding forced a suspension of all shuttle flights until Discovery,
Endeavour, Atlantis and Columbia could be inspected and repaired.


   Discovery was towed to its launch pad at NASA's Kennedy Space
Center in Florida on Saturday.


   Meanwhile, the latest gyroscope failure forced the space
telescope into an electronic slumber called a ``safe mode.'' The
operating mode ensures that the telescope continues to generate
electricity for its scientific equipment and flight controls,
though it is unable to point at celestial targets.


   The gyroscope stopped after experiencing a sudden power surge.
The previous failures followed successive electrical
irregularities, some spanning several weeks.


   ``This underscores the wisdom of scheduling this call-up service
mission,'' said David Leckrone, the Hubble's senior project
scientist at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md.,
where the observatory is managed. ``We will only lose about three
weeks of science observations. Had we not split the mission and
proceeded with our June 2000 mission we would be facing a
seven-month interruption.''


   In addition to replacing all six gyroscopes next month,
spacewalking astronauts plan to install a faster flight computer, a
solid state data recorder, a new transmitter, another large
guidance device as well as new external insulation.


   &QL; 
 &QL; 
XXXX END OF STORY &QL;

results.content:
By MARK CARREAU &QL;


   c. 1999 &QL;


   Houston Chronicle &QL;


   HOUSTON _ Perhaps not since the launching of the Hubble Space
Telescope nearly a decade ago have astronomers awaited the arrival
of a new celestial observatory with such anticipation.


   NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory, a $1.55 billion, 45-foot-long,
high-tech assembly of precision-ground optics and science
instruments, promises at least a 10-fold improvement over previous
telescopes of its type, but many involved in the project predict
the improvements will be in the order of 100-fold.


   If successfully launched by the crew of the shuttle Columbia,
the Chandra will permit a relatively new breed of scientist _ the
X-ray astronomers _ to study the boundaries of black holes, chart
the locale of the mysterious dark matter that is believed to
comprise much of the universe, and trace the cosmic production of
the carbon, oxygen, iron and the other heavy elements that coalesce
to form stars, planets and the molecular ingredients of life as we
know it.


   ``So much of this must sound like science fiction,'' said Harvey
Tananbaum, who will direct Chandra observations from the
Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics in Cambridge, Mass.
``But in truth, it will be much better than science fiction because
in a few weeks we will actually be doing it.''


   At Cambridge, Tananbaum's team has sifted through 800 proposals
from astronomers around the world eager to use the telescope after
it completes its two-month orbital check-out. Only 200 requests
have been approved.


   Columbia is scheduled to blast off with the telescope tonight
(Monday) &UR;  &LR; at 11:36 p.m. CDT from NASA's Kennedy Space Center in
Florida. Led by Eileen Collins, the first woman to command a
shuttle crew, the five astronauts plan to deploy the new
observatory and its two-stage propulsion system, within eight
hours.


   ``This is a historic moment, an exciting moment for
astrophysics,'' said Martin Weisskopf, Chandra's chief astronomer
on the eve of the liftoff. ``This is an age when superlatives are
used in everything from sports to politics, probably a little bit
too much. But I can't help but use these superlatives with this
telescope.''


   As one of just four large major space telescopes envisioned by
NASA for its post-Apollo years and dubbed the Great Observatories,
Chandra is all about superlatives.


   Two decades of development at the Marshall Space Flight Center
in Huntsville, Ala., five to 10 years of orbital operations, a
shuttle launch and construction of a one-of-a-kind, ground-based
optical testing facility will bring the total estimated mission
cost to $2.8 billion.


   ``This is a very big program,'' acknowledged Ed Weiler, NASA's
associate administrator for space science. ``We are putting a lot
of eggs in one basket. If it works like we think it will, it will
be well worth the investment, just like the Hubble was.''


   Earlier this year, the space agency agreed to extend the
Hubble's orbital life from 15 to 20 years, enabling it to probe the
boundaries of the universe. But as Hubble's former chief
astronomer, Weiler recalls well that telescope's nightmarish
beginning. Weeks after it reached orbit in 1990, astronomers
discovered its primary mirror was misshapen, blurring its vision
and shaking public confidence in NASA.


   Three years later, shuttle astronauts managed to correct the
difficulties with a do-or-die repair mission.


   ``The Hubble problem sent shivers through everyone in the space
science business,'' said Weiler. ``A lot of important lessons were
learned. The important thing is not only did we learn those
lessons, but we acted on them.''


   Chandra was headed toward an August 1998 liftoff when engineers
at Marshall and its prime contractor, California-based TRW,
discovered problems in the craft's computer software. Then the
supplier of critical electronic circuity disclosed problems with
similar components on another satellite. In April, the Air Force
lost a missile-warning satellite when its Boeing-made Inertial
Upper Stage, the

results.content:
DISCOVERY CREW PREPARES TO GRAB HUBBLE 




   The Discovery astronauts raced after the disabled Hubble Space
Telescope on Monday as they readied spacesuits, dozens of hand
tools and other equipment for a high-tech service call.


   The seven-man shuttle crew was on course to reach the
42-foot-long observatory late Tuesday. European Space Agency
astronaut Jean Francois Clervoy was to grab the observatory with
Discovery's 50-foot-long robot arm shortly before 8 p.m. EST. Once
nabbed, the towering observatory will be secured upright atop a
rotating work platform within the shuttle's cargo bay.


   The delicate operation more than 360 miles above the Earth will
set the stage for a series of three long spacewalks this week by
astronauts Steve Smith, John Grunsfeld, Mike Foale and Claude
Nicollier to repair the Hubble's crippled pointing system and make
other repairs.


   Discovery's pursuit of the space telescope began Sunday night as
the shuttle soared into orbit from its Florida launching complex,
while the Hubble sailed high above Central Africa.


   It was the first shuttle launching since the late July liftoff
of Columbia was jeopardized by an electrical short. Later traced to
chaffed insulation in fuselage wiring, Columbia's short prompted
the space agency to suspend launchings while all of the winged
ships underwent extensive inspections and wiring repairs.


   Though the bulk of the eight-day mission lies ahead, NASA was
clearly pleased to see Discovery in orbit after a record nine
delays. The postponements spanned more than two months as shuttle
managers embraced a more cautious approach after the wiring
problems and called for additional scrutiny and repairs to a rocket
engine as well as to external cabling and Discovery's propulsion
and hydraulic systems.


   ``We're back in business,'' mission control cabled Discovery
commander Curt Brown early Monday as the astronauts began their
first full day in orbit.


   The astronauts spent most of the day preparing Discovery's robot
arm, the airlock, the spacesuits, and more than 300 hand tools for
tasks ahead. The tasks went smoothly, though one of the spacesuits
had a weak battery that was replaced.


   Late Monday, the shuttle astronauts closed to within 1,200 miles
of the orbital observatory, and for the first time during their
flight maneuvered to slow rather than increase the closure rate.


   Working closely with NASA's mission control, Brown and pilot
Scott Kelly will increase the number of maneuvers Tuesday to refine
the rendezvous. When Discovery reaches a point 2,500 feet below the
telescope, Brown will began to manually steer the shuttle close
enough for Clervoy to grapple it.


   Celestial observations with the telescope ceased in mid-November
when the Hubble experienced its fourth gyro failure in two years.
The loss disabled the pointing system that permits ground-based
astronomers to aim the telescope at distant stars and galaxies for
lengthy observations.


   Smith and Grunsfeld will address the gyro loss during the
mission's first spacewalk on Wednesday by replacing all six of the
devices.


   With that task complete, the spacewalkers plan to expend their
work by replacing the Hubble's flight computer; a data recorder and
transmitter that store stellar images of the celestial objects
studied by astronomers and relay them to Earth; and make other
improvements to the power and guidance systems. As time permits,
the spacewalkers are equipped to patch damage to the external
insulation of the observatory caused by solar radiation.


   ``Obviously, we are pleased,'' NASA's Don McMonagle, Discovery's
mission management team chairman, said of the shuttle program's
change in fortune. ``We have a darn near perfect vehicle in orbit
right now. We couldn't ask for a better scenario to execute this
mission.''


   &QL; 
XXXX END OF STORY &QL;

results.content:
HUNDREDS GREET SUCCESSFUL SHUTTLE ASTRONAUTS 




   HOUSTON _ Several hundred well-wishers greeted NASA's Discovery
astronauts Tuesday as they returned to Houston following their
successful mission to repair the Hubble Space Telescope.


   Discovery's eight-day flight ended Monday night with a landing
at NASA's Kennedy Space Center in Florida. After medical exams, a
reunion with family members and a rest, they flew back to their
Houston-area homes Tuesday.


   ``Did we have an awesome mission or what?'' Discovery commander
Curt Brown asked the crowd of mostly Johnson Space Center workers
that greeted him and the six other astronauts as they arrived at
Ellington Field.


   ``I think we did a great job,'' said Brown as he, pilot Scott
Kelly, flight engineer Jean Francois Clervoy, Steve Smith, Mike
Foale, John Grunsfeld and Claude Nicollier received a round of
applause.


   During their eight days in space, Discovery's astronauts
rendezvoused with the Hubble Space Telescope and with three
spacewalks restored its disabled pointing control system and made
other repairs. No longer able to conduct astronomical observations
when the shuttle astronauts arrived, the Hubble is scheduled to
resume science activities in January as a result of their efforts.


   ``Hubble will show us things we never imagined,'' predicted
Grunsfeld, an astronomer turned astronaut who was among the
spacewalk repair team. ``What we will see will really blow our
minds.''


   The $4 billion observatory was launched in 1990. Discovery's
visit and others planned by the shuttle in 2001 and 2003 are
intended to keep the Hubble operational until 2010.


   &QL; 
XXXX END OF STORY &QL;

results.content:
SHUTTLE LAUNCH TO HUBBLE SET FOR THURSDAY 




   NASA has replaced a bent fuel line on the space shuttle
Discovery and plans a Thursday launch on a much-delayed mission to
repair the Hubble Space Telescope.


   Discovery and a crew of seven astronauts are to lift off at 9:18
p.m. EST from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. The mission
countdown was to begin early Tuesday.


   Efforts to launch the mission last week were halted before a
countdown could begin when workers discovered a bent 6-foot-long
line that recirculates chilled liquid hydrogen between the rocket
engines and the shuttle's large external fuel tank.


   Shuttle managers authorized the launch attempt after the line
was successfully replaced and tested.


   Plans for a 10-day mission will place Discovery and its crew in
space over Christmas.


   Once Discovery reaches the Hubble, astronauts John Grunsfeld,
Mike Foale, Claude Nicollier and Steve Smith have prepared for a
series of four spacewalks to replace the space telescope's six
gyroscopes, a crucial component of the observatory's pointing
system, and make other repairs.


   Hubble observations were halted Nov. 13 following the failure of
a fourth gyro.


   While the gyro replacements are the mission's highest priority,
Discovery's crew also plans to replace the telescope's flight
computer, a data recorder, a data transmitter and another pointing
system component called the fine guidance sensor.


   Though they have approved a rare mission over Christmas, shuttle
managers have said Discovery must be back on the ground by Dec. 28
to avoid any Y2K glitches, though none is anticipated.


   In order to meet that restriction, Discovery must lift off by
Saturday night or wait until January.


   The flight was initially planned for mid-October. However, all
missions were halted when the July launching of the shuttle
Columbia experienced an electrical short moments after lift off.


   The short was traced to damaged insulation on wiring in
Columbia's fuselage. The finding prompted inspections and repairs
to all of the shuttles, including Discovery.


   Other setbacks required the replacement of a shuttle rocket
engine and wiring outside the fuselage linking the external tank
and the solid rocket boosters.


   &QL; 
XXXX END OF STORY &QL;

results.content:
NASA TO COMPLETE HUBBLE REPAIRS BEFORE NEW YEAR TO AVOID Y2K
WORRIES 



   WASHINGTON _ To avoid Y2K computer problems, NASA is taking
steps to make sure the shuttle Discovery completes its mission to
repair the Hubble space telescope before the new year, even if it
means flying over the Christmas holiday, a space agency official
said Friday.


   Ron Dittemore, NASA's shuttle program director, said the agency
had tested and adjusted its computers and their programs and did
not anticipate any problems when the year changes to 2000. But NASA
does not intend to take any chances by having a shuttle and crew in
orbit on New Year's Day, he said.


   ``We've decided prudently that we're not going to fly past the
end of the year,'' Dittemore said in a telephone interview from
Johnson Space Center in Houston. ``Since we don't have to do it, we
won't do it.''


   Both the flight software for the shuttle, designed to guide it
from liftoff to landing, and computer programs used by Mission
Control to manage the voyage have been tested and certified as
being Y2K compliant, Dittemore said.


   NASA decided last spring to speed up scheduled servicing of
Hubble because some of the gyroscopes that stabilize the $2 billion
telescope had failed. Three of the 12.5 ton observatory's six gyros
have failed and the loss of one more would cause the telescope to
go into a hibernation mode for safekeeping, ending valuable
scientific observations until repairs are made.


   The agency decided to split the Hubble service mission scheduled
for June 2000 into two parts and make some modifications and
repairs, including installing new gyroscopes, in a nine-day flight
originally set for mid-October. The second service mission is set
for May 2001.


   Last summer electrical wiring problems were found in the
four-shuttle fleet requiring extensive inspection and repairs,
pushing Discovery's mission into December, officials said. Shuttle
managers decided this week to replace one of the shuttle's three
main engines, a task that they say could further delay liftoff
several days past the current target date, Dec. 2.


   Discovery is scheduled to be fitted with its external fuel tank
and solid-fuel booster rockets this weekend and then moved to a
launching pad, where technicians will replace the engine. Managers
expect to set a new launch date next week.


   In order to speed preparations for the flight, shuttle managers
decided to use software from a 1997 service mission to Hubble
instead of writing new programs. This raised initial concerns about
Y2K compatibility, but Dittemore said the software had been tested
and cleared.


   NASA normally does not fly missions that coincide with major
holidays to give its employees time off and to avoid overtime pay.
However, Dittemore said, the Hubble mission is so important that
the agency decided not to make the Christmas holidays a factor in
its decision to fly.


   ``Our primary driver is the end of the year and not flying then,
so we probably would not consider a launch date past Dec. 14,'' he
said, ``We want to have the shuttle back and done with its initial
post-flight processing by Dec. 28th or 29th.''


   During this Hubble service mission, traditionally one of the
most challenging jobs for shuttle crews, pairs of astronauts are to
conduct four space walks to replace all six gyroscopes, exchange
the observatory's main computer with a faster model, replace a data
recorder, add a new fine-guidance sensor and make other
adjustments.

results.content:
COUNTDOWN BEGINS FOR SHUTTLE LAUNCH TO REPAIR HUBBLE 




   CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. _ After weeks of setbacks, the countdown
for what NASA bills as an urgent shuttle mission to replace the
Hubble Space Telescope's faltering gyroscopes was finally under way
Tuesday.


   The shuttle Discovery, with seven astronauts aboard, is
scheduled to blast off at 9:18 p.m. EST Thursday from the Kennedy
Space Center for a 10-day repair mission. Successive failures of
the Hubble's gyroscopes, a crucial component of the telescope's
precision pointing system, forced astronomers to halt celestial
observations a month ago.


   The flight will mark only the third shuttle mission of the year,
the fewest since 1988, when a beleaguered NASA was recovering from
the fatal 1986 Challenger accident.


   Space agency officials say this year's slower pace is driven by
a new sense of caution prompted by the electrical short that
jeopardized the July launching of the shuttle Columbia with the
Chandra X-Ray Observatory.


   The incident prompted NASA to suspend future launch plans while
it looked for the cause and to inspect its shuttles for other
problems.


   ``The guys are taking a very close look at everything,'' said
Ron Dittemore, NASA's shuttle program manager. ``Maybe something we
would have flown with in the past and maybe not brought up as a big
deal _ these things are under a microscope and elevated to the
top.''


   Columbia's short was traced to damaged insulation on the
electrical wiring buried in the shuttle's fuselage. When shuttle
managers ordered inspections of Discovery as well as Endeavour and
Atlantis, similar insulation nicks were found. Engineers concluded
the damage was inadvertent but caused by shuttle ground personnel
as they repeatedly placed work platforms against the wiring as they
prepared the winged spacecraft for past missions.


   Eventually, 57 repairs to the fuselage wiring of Discovery were
required, and NASA is revising the procedures and modifying the
equipment its ground forces use to work on the shuttle as a result
of Columbia's problems.


   Meanwhile, plans announced by NASA in March for a mid-October
shuttle visit to Hubble to fix the ailing gyros slipped seven times
as shuttle managers dealt with the wiring problems and learned of
other safety threats.


   The new problems ranged from a bent fuel line and a rocket
engine containing a broken drill bit that had to be replaced to a
leaking hydraulic system that had to be fixed. Wiring harnesses
outside the fuselage also required unscheduled replacements or
repairs. The launchings of Endeavour and Atlantis that were planned
for late this year have slipped into late January and mid-March.


   As Discovery's countdown began, shuttle managers were hopeful
the obstacles were behind them.


   They have prepared for consecutive launch attempts Thursday,
Friday and Saturday, if necessary, before postponing Discovery's
launching until mid-January. Typically, NASA makes two consecutive
launching attempts, then allows its personnel to rest on the third
day before resuming the countdown.


   But the space agency wants Discovery's crew back on the ground
no later than Dec. 28. Though it has ensured the shuttle's software
is Y2K compliant, the space agency does not plan to risk any
computer problems by flying on New Year's Eve.


   That means several hundred personnel in the mission control
facility at the Johnson Space Center in Houston will work over
Christmas, a rarity for NASA but something that will become common
place as it assembles the international space station.


   According to forecasters, the prospects of favorable weather
conditions for Thursday and Friday are 80 percent, with low clouds
the only concern. Conditions deteriorate slightly Saturday, when
rain is a possibility.


   Once in orbit, Discovery's crew plans to rendezvous with the
42-foot-long telescope and grapple it with the shuttle's
50-foot-long robot arm.


   After the telescope has been secured in Discovery's cargo bay,
astronauts Steve Smith, John Grunsfeld, Mike Foale and Claude
Ni

results.content:
MISSION TO HUBBLE MOVES AHEAD OF MAPPING FLIGHT 
 




   HOUSTON _ NASA said Thursday it plans to swap the order of the
two shuttle missions that remain this year, placing a trip to the
Hubble Space Telescope ahead of an Earth-mapping flight.


   Shuttle launches have been suspended since the late July flight
of Columbia with the Chandra X-ray Observatory. The space agency
ordered repairs to dozens of miles of electrical wiring in
Endeavour, which had been scheduled for a mid-September liftoff;
Discovery, which been targeted for a mid-October flight; and
Atlantis, which was scheduled for an early December trip.


   With work this week running 70 percent complete on Discovery and
60 percent complete on Endeavour, the space agency elected Thursday
to flip the order of the flights and establish tentative launch
dates.


   Discovery will lift off no earlier than Oct. 28 with a crew of
seven for a 10-day mission to the Hubble Space Telescope. The
orbiting observatory's pointing control system is in need of new
gyroscopes.


   Endeavour and a crew of six will launch no sooner than Nov. 19
on an 11-day flight with a radar apparatus designed to produce a
three-dimensional map of the Earth's surface.


   The dates are considered targets and could change as the repair
efforts are reassessed next week.


   Also driving flight plans is the annual late November Leonid
meteor shower. For the last several years, the space agency has
observed a hiatus in shuttle missions during the most intense
period of the shower, around Nov. 18, when there is an increased
risk of collision.


   &QL; 
XXXX END OF STORY &QL;

1999-10-07 14:10:38 
 usa 
 Hubble Repair Bumped to December 


	CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (AP) -- NASA has bumped space shuttle  
Discovery's flight to the Hubble Space Telescope to December so 
workers can complete wiring and valve repairs. 


	Shuttle managers said Thursday they're targeting a Dec. 2 launch  
date for Discovery. The telescope-repair mission had been scheduled 
for mid-October, then mid-November. 


	A radar-mapping mission by Endeavour, meanwhile, has been moved  
to January. And the next flight to the international space station, 
by Atlantis, is now set for February. 


	The missions were delayed following Columbia's marred launch in  
July. A short circuit five seconds into the flight knocked out 
computers for two of the three main engines; defective wiring was 
to blame. Wiring defects subsequently were found in the other 
shuttles. 


	NASA also is contending with bad valves aboard Discovery. Two  
leaking valves in the right orbital maneuvering system must be 
replaced. 


	With only two shuttle launches so far in 1999, and only one more  
scheduled, this will be the leanest year for NASA since shuttles 
resumed flying in 1988 following the Challenger disaster.
