results.content:
SHUTTLE MISSION TO REPAIR HUBBLE TELESCOPE AGAIN DELAYED 




   CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. _ The launch of the shuttle Discovery on a
much-delayed mission to repair the Hubble Space Telescope was
postponed for a day Thursday so engineers could widen a search for
improperly welded components in the shuttle's fuel lines.


   The launch was reset for 8:47 p.m. EST Friday. Forecasters
predict a 60 percent probability of low clouds or rain during the
42-minute launch period.


   NASA has said it will postpone all efforts to launch the mission
until January if Discovery is not off the ground by Saturday night.


   Thursday's postponement forced shuttle managers to trim the
length of the flight from 10 to nine days. NASA has prohibited its
shuttles from flying over New Year's Eve and wants Discovery back
on the ground no later than Dec. 28 as a precaution against
so-called Y2K computer problems. However, it believes the
spacecraft faces no software issues.


   The shorter mission will permit the four lengthy spacewalks that
Discovery's crew plans to replace the Hubble's faltering gyroscopes
and make other repairs. The seven astronauts will give up a
scheduled off-duty day in orbit to preserve the spacewalks.


   ``This is disappointing,'' said Ron Dittemore, NASA's shuttle
program manager, who has presided over eight setbacks since
Discovery was initially scheduled to liftoff in mid-October.


   The latest issue arose late Tuesday when a California company
that supplies propellant lines for the shuttle's external fuel tank
alerted NASA that an improper metal alloy had been used to weld a
fuel line slated for use on a future mission.


   As a precaution, shuttle engineers worked quickly to review
X-rays of the welds on Discovery's fuel tank. They said Wednesday
night that Discovery's tank was OK.


   However, on Thursday shuttle contractors asked NASA for more
time to expand the analysis to the welds in a dozen steel alloy
propellant lines and other components within Discovery's tail
section, where the ship's three rocket engines are housed.


   Dittemore then called a halt to the countdown so engineers could
reassess 20-year-old records of the welding and inspection
procedures used in the fabrication of the 17-inch wide hydrogen and
oxygen lines and subassemblies in the engine compartment.


   ``I don't think there is a hardware problem. What we have to do
is search over the paperwork to convince ourselves that this is not
an issue,'' said Dittemore. ``If this had happened two or three
days ago, it would be cleared up by now.''


   Unlike the shuttle's 15-story tall fuel tank, which is disposed
of after each launch, the components within Discovery's engine
compartment have already flown 26 previous missions dating back to
1984.


   Like its sister shuttle orbiters, Discovery was designed to fly
at least 100 missions.


   NASA's concern over the welds on the fuel tank were limited to
whether they could withstand the stresses of a single lift off.
With the components inside the shuttle, the concern expands to
whether the welds can withstand years of fatigue, Dittemore said.


   Shuttle missions have been suspended since Columbia experienced
an electrical short moments after its late July lift off. The short
was traced to damaged electrical working in Columbia's fuselage.
The finding prompted the space agency to inspect and repair the
wiring on the shuttles, starting with Discovery.


   Subsequently, other problems with Discovery contributed to the
delays. The space agency has replaced a rocket engine, repaired
external cables and wiring, fixed a leaky hydraulic system and
replaced a dented fuel line.


   Astronomical observations with Hubble were halted Nov. 13 after
the fourth of the telescope's six gyroscopes malfunctioned. Without
at least three working gyros, the observatory cannot be aimed
precisely enough to study stars, galaxies and other distant objects
in the universe.


   ``It's as frustrating today as it was yesterday and the day
before,'' NASA's Dave Leckrone, the Hubble's senior project
scientists, sai
